Tobati.alt_name: Enggros, Humboldt Jotafa, Jayapura, Jotafa, Tobwadic, Yautefa, Yotafa
Tobati.name: Tobati
Tobati.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Jayapura Bay
Tobati.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tobati
Tobati.dialects: None known. Formerly classified as Papuan.
Tobati.language_use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Mainly assimilated to Indonesian [ind] language and culture. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].
Tobati.location: Papua province: Enggros, Entrop, Kota Raja, Tanah Hitam, and Tobati villages on Jayapura bay.

Kaimbulawa.name: Kaimbulawa
Kaimbulawa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Munan, Munic
Kaimbulawa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kaimbulawa
Kaimbulawa.dialects: Kambe-Kambero, Kaimbulawa (Lontoi). Not a dialect of Muna
Kaimbulawa.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Kaimbulawa and Lantoi villages on Siompu island, southwest Buton island, Kambe-kambero village.

Morori.name: Morori
Morori.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Morori
Morori.dialects: Menge dialect remembered as the language of ceremony, though the last Menge speaker died in 1997.
Morori.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Marind [mrz], a language group which surrounds the Morori, and from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Mainly older adults. All also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Marind [mrz]. Used as L2 by Bädi Kanum [khd], Ngkâlmpw Kanum [kcd], Smärky Kanum [kxq], Sota Kanum [krz].
Morori.location: Papua province: south coast border area.
Morori.population: 50 (1998 M. Donohue). Ethnic population: 250 (1998 M. Donohue).

Walak.name: Walak
Walak.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Dani, Dani Proper
Walak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Walak
Walak.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency, Bugi village; Central Mamberano regency, Ilugwa, Mogonik, Wodo, and Wurigelebur villages.

Seit-Kaitetu.name: Seit-Kaitetu
Seit-Kaitetu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, West, Asilulu
Seit-Kaitetu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Seit-Kaitetu
Seit-Kaitetu.dialects: Seit (Seith), Kaitetu. Lexical similarity: 85% between Kaitetu and Seit dialects. Lexical similarity: 78%–82% with Asilulu
Seit-Kaitetu.location: Maluku Province, Maluku Tengah regency, Piru bay, Ambon island, north coast: Seit and Kaitetu villages.

Bakumpai.status: 3 (Wider communication). Used as a LWC in the market in central Kalimantan Province.
Bakumpai.name: Bakumpai
Bakumpai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, West, South
Bakumpai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bakumpai
Bakumpai.dialects: Bakumpai, Mengkatip (Mangkatip, Oloh Mengkatip). Lexical similarity: 75% with Ngaju
Bakumpai.language_use: Used as L2 by Dusun Deyah [dun], Dusun Witu [duw], Lawangan [lbx], Ma’anyan [mhy].
Bakumpai.location: Kalimantan Tengah province: Barito Selatan, and Barito Utara, and Kapuas regencies, Kapuas and Barito rivers; possibly southernmost Murung Raya regency.

Wolani.name: Wolani
Wolani.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Wolani
Wolani.location: Papua province: west central highlands, Kemandoga and Mbiyandogo rivers area northeast of Lake Paniai, north of Wissel Lakes.

Sedoa.name: Sedoa
Sedoa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Kaili-Pamona, Northern, Kaili
Sedoa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sedoa
Sedoa.dialects: Not a dialect of nearby Napu
Sedoa.location: Sulawesi Tengah Province, Lore Utara subdistrict, Sedoa village; Poso Pesisir subdistrict, parts of Tambarona and Pinedapa villages.

Kalao.name: Kalao
Kalao.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kalao
Kalao.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 76% with Laiyolo
Kalao.language_use: Under pressure from Bonerate [bna] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Kalao.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Kepulauan Selayar regency, Selayar islands; east Kalao island.

Mamuju.name: Mamuju
Mamuju.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Mamuju
Mamuju.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mamuju
Mamuju.dialects: Mamuju, Sumare-Rangas, Padang, Sinyonyoi. Mamuju dialect is prestigious.
Mamuju.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Mamuju regency, Budong-Budong, Kalukku, and Mamuju sub-districts; Point Rangas north along Makassar strait coast to Limba town area.

Kamarian.name: Kamarian
Kamarian.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Uliase, Kamarian
Kamarian.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kamarian
Kamarian.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 75% with Kaibobo
Kamarian.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Barat regency, southwest Seram island inland from Ceram strait, Haruku, and Sapura islands.
Kamarian.population: No known L1 speakers (Wurm 2007). Under 10 in 1987; now probably extinct (Wurm 2007). Ethnic population: 6,000 (1987 SIL).

Malay, Central.alt_name: Bengkulu, Besemah, Enim, Lintang, Melayu Tengah, Midden Maleisch, Ogan, Pasemah, Semendo, Serawai
Malay, Central.name: Malay, Central
Malay, Central.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Central
Malay, Central.dialects: Serawai, Bengkulu, Semenda, Lintang, Benakat, Kisam, Pasemah, Kikim, Lematang Ulu, Ogan, Enim, Rambang. Lexical similarity: 75% with Kaur
Malay, Central.language_use: Vigorous. Home, village, commerce, religion. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Musi [mui].
Malay, Central.language_development: Indonesian [ind] preferred for educational and religious materials, but L1 for cultural stories and songs. Mixed preference for health and agricultural materials. Taught in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Malay, Central.location: Bengkulu province: central Bukit Barisan highlands west to Indian Ocean along Bengkulu coast; Lampung province; Sumatera Selatan province: Lematang and Ogan river valleys.

Burumakok.name: Burumakok
Burumakok.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Burumakok
Burumakok.location: Papua province: Pegunungan Bintang regency, Kurima sub-district, Burumakok village.

Dao.name: Dao
Dao.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dao
Dao.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 75% with Auye
Dao.language_use: Home, community. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].
Dao.location: Papua province: Paniai regency, Napan sub-district; west central highlands along Dao river.

Dai.name: Dai
Dai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Babar, North
Dai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dai
Dai.dialects: No dialect variation. Lexical similarity: 72% with Dawera-Daweloor (most similar)
Dai.language_use: Vigorous. Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], specifically a regional variety, in the home, garden, ceremonies; children are taught this variety first and later become proficient in the vernacular. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.
Dai.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency, Sinairusi, 3 other villages on Lewa island.

Buru.name: Buru
Buru.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, Buru
Buru.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Buru
Buru.dialects: Masarete (South Buru), Wae Sama (Waesama), Central Buru (Rana, Wae Geren, Wae Kabo), Fogi (Li Emteban, Tomahu). Li Garan is a special taboo dialect spoken by the Rana people (3,000 to 5,000 users). Ethnic population Fogi dialect: 500, but no remaining speakers. Lexical similarity: 90% between Masarete and Wae Sama dialects, 88% between Masarete and Rana, 80% between Wae Sama and Rana, 68% between Lisela
Buru.other_comments: There are word taboos and complex intermarriage patterns on the island. Exogamous. 10 clans. Christian, Muslim, traditional religion.
Buru.language_use: Vigorous in most areas. Fogi dialect speakers apparently shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs]. All domains. All ages. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], Indonesian [ind].
Buru.location: Maluku province: Buru island except northeast corner, 70 villages; some on Ambon island in Jakarta.
Buru.typology: SVO; prepositions; genitives before nouns; predominantly head marking; CV, CVC, V, VC; nontonal.

Yoke.name: Yoke
Yoke.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yoke
Yoke.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 33% with Warembori
Yoke.language_use: Vigorous. Religious services. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Warembori [wsa]. Used as L2 by Warembori [wsa].
Yoke.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Mantarbori village northeast of Rombebai lake, east of Mamberamo river.

Bantik.name: Bantik
Bantik.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bantik
Bantik.language_use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Fluent users age 50 or older. Positive attitudes. Also use Manado Malay [xmm].
Bantik.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Manado city area, 11 villages; north peninsula, northeast section.

Palu\u2019e.name: Palu’e
Palu\u2019e.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Palu’e
Palu\u2019e.dialects: None known. Possible grouping with Ende
Palu\u2019e.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Palu’e island; Flores mainland, Nangahure village northwest of Maumere.

Berik.alt_name: Berick, Berrik, Sewan Teteris, Upper Tor
Berik.name: Berik
Berik.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Berik
Berik.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 45% with Keijar
Berik.other_comments: Formerly the trade language of Tor area. Christian, traditional religion.
Berik.language_use: Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Mander [mqr].
Berik.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Tor Atas sub-district, Beu, Bora Bora, Dangken, Doronta, Kondirjan, Safrontani, Sewan, Somanente, Taminambor, Tenwer, Togonfo, and Waf villages; north coast, mid and upper Tor river, inland from Sarmi peninsula.

Mer.name: Mer
Mer.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mer
Mer.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 63% with Semimi
Mer.location: Papua province: Nabire regency; Papua Barat province: Kaimana and Teluk Wondama regencies on central Bird’s Head, headwaters of Uremo and Wosimi rivers.

Tunjung.name: Tunjung
Tunjung.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tunjung
Tunjung.dialects: Tunjung (Tunjung Tengah), Tunjung Londong, Tunjung Linggang, Pahu.
Tunjung.location: Kalimantan Tengah province: North Barito regency border area; Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai Barat and Kutai Kartanegara regencies between Adas, Dempar, and Melak towns, then down Mahakam river, east around Djempang lake.

Rajong.name: Rajong
Rajong.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Rajong
Rajong.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Central Flores island near Mount Watuweri, 2 areas.

Yale, Kosarek.name: Yale, Kosarek
Yale, Kosarek.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yale, Kosarek
Yale, Kosarek.dialects: Kosarek, Gilika (Kilika), Tiple. Lexical similarity: 78% with Nipsan
Yale, Kosarek.other_comments: The name In-lom refers to only half the group. Christian, traditional religion.
Yale, Kosarek.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. Negative attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Yale, Kosarek.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Bible portions: 1992–1996.
Yale, Kosarek.population: 2,300 (1993 R. Doriot). 2,300 monolinguals. Nearly 100% are monolingual. Ethnic population: 2,300.

Nafri.name: Nafri
Nafri.classification: East Bird’s Head-Sentani, Sentani, Sentani Proper
Nafri.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nafri
Nafri.location: Papua province: Jayapura area, Nafri village on southeast Yotafa bay.

Koneraw.name: Koneraw
Koneraw.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Koneraw
Koneraw.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Kimaghima [kig] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Koneraw.location: Papua province: Merauke regency, Kolopom island south coast.

Te\u2019un.name: Te’un
Te\u2019un.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Teun-Nila-Serua, Teun
Te\u2019un.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Te’un
Te\u2019un.other_comments: Government moved them from Teun Island, south central Maluku, due to volcanic activity on their island.
Te\u2019un.location: Maluku province: 4 villages on central and south central Seram island.

Sekar.name: Sekar
Sekar.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, North Bomberai
Sekar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sekar
Sekar.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: highest with Arguni
Sekar.location: Papua Barat province: Fakfak regency, Kokas area on northwest Bomberai peninsula coast; Ogar island.

Gresi.name: Gresi
Gresi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Gresi
Gresi.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 80% with Kemtuik
Gresi.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Bring, Hawa, Ibub, Klaysu, Sunna, Tabangkwari, and Yansu villages.

Tontemboan.name: Tontemboan
Tontemboan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tontemboan
Tontemboan.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Minahasa Selatan regency on Amurang bay inland; Minahasa and Minahasa Tenggara regencies, Lake Tondano southeast strip to coast.

Kaili, Da\u2019a.alt_name: Binggi, Bunggu, Da’a, Pakawa, Pekava, Pekawa
Kaili, Da\u2019a.name: Kaili, Da’a
Kaili, Da\u2019a.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Kaili-Pamona, Northern, Kaili
Kaili, Da\u2019a.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kaili, Da’a
Kaili, Da\u2019a.dialects: Da’a (Dombu), Inde. Some intelligibility of Ledo dialect of Kaili, Ledo
Kaili, Da\u2019a.other_comments: ‘Bunggu’ is the name used for Da’a and Inde in West Sulawesi (Mamuju regency, Pasangkayu sub-district). Christian.
Kaili, Da\u2019a.language_use: Vigorous. Most children know little Indonesian [ind] when entering school. All domains. Oral use in local administration, commerce, school. Some oral and written use in church. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially in church.
Kaili, Da\u2019a.location: Sulawesi Tengah and Sulawesi Barat provinces: Banawa, Dolo, Marawola, Palolo, and Sigi-Biromaru sub-districts.
Kaili, Da\u2019a.population: 55,000 (2007 SIL), increasing. 3,000–5,000 Da’a and Inde in south Sulawesi. Many monolinguals.

Sunum.name: Sunum
Sunum.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Sarmi
Sunum.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sunum
Sunum.language_use: More vigorous on mainland than on island. Mainly older adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Sunum.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Pantai Timur sub-district, coastal area and Nirumoar island.

Auye.name: Auye
Auye.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Auye
Auye.language_use: Influence from Ekari [ekg] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Auye.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Bible portions: 1993–2007.
Auye.location: Papua province: Paniai regency, Napan sub-district; central highlands in Siriwo river area.

Meoswar.name: Meoswar
Meoswar.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Biakic
Meoswar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Meoswar
Meoswar.location: Papua Barat province: Meoswar island, west Cenderawasih bay.

Alune.name: Alune
Alune.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Three Rivers, Amalumute, Northwest Seram, Ulat Inai
Alune.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Alune
Alune.dialects: Kairatu, Central West Alune (Niniari-Piru-Riring-Lumoli), South Alune (Rambatu-Manussa-Rumberu), North Coastal Alune (Nikulkan-Murnaten-Wakolo), Central East Alune (Buriah-Weth-Laturake). Rambatu dialect reportedly prestigious. Kawe
Alune.other_comments: Largest language in west Seram. Christian.
Alune.language_use: People in the interior, the majority, use it daily. Coastal village usage less vigorous. Southern dialect in Kairatu village has no remaining speakers. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Alune.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–65%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–55%. NT: 2012.
Alune.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Barat regency, Kairatu and Taniwel districts, 27 villages in Latuhelu area and Piru bay.

Moraid.name: Moraid
Moraid.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Moraid
Moraid.location: Papua Barat province: west Bird’s Head inland, Mata to Worbo area.

Maiwa.name: Maiwa
Maiwa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Masenrempulu
Maiwa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Maiwa
Maiwa.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Enrekang and Sidenrang-Rappang regencies; Boya river area.

Gebe.name: Gebe
Gebe.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Raja Ampat
Gebe.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Gebe
Gebe.other_comments: A school in each village. Muslim.
Gebe.language_use: Mining operations started in the area which led to more schooling of children and increasing use of Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). All domains. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Gebe.location: Maluku Utara province: Gag, Gebe, and Yoi’umiya islands, 4 villages; Papua Barat province: Halmahera island.

Yaqay.name: Yaqay
Yaqay.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yaqay
Yaqay.language_use: Home, religious services. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Yaqay.location: Papua province: Mappi regency, south coast along Obaa river north to Gandaimu area.

Sekak.alt_name: Lonchong, Loncong, Lontjong, Orang Laut, Orang Sawang, Sawang, Seka, Sekah
Sekak.name: Sekak
Sekak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sekak
Sekak.dialects: Lexically and phonologically distinct from the Belitung dialect of Malay
Sekak.other_comments: Southernmost of dozens of Malayic-speaking Orang Laut, sea tribe, groups ranging from the waters of Thailand through the Riau archipelago and Bangka and Belitung. Traditional religion.
Sekak.location: Sumatra, Kepulauan Bangka Belitung Province, Bangka Barat, Banka Tenga, and Bangka Selantan regencies, 2 coastal enclaves northern and southeast Bangka island; Belitung regency, western Belitung, Lepar, Liat, Mendanau, and other islands.

Galela.name: Galela
Galela.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Galela
Galela.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Galela.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera Selatan regency, Bisa island, Koto Wonto area; Obi island: Laiwai and Sesepe area, and Woi Lower and Wui islands on south coast; Kasiratua, Mandioli, and Obit islands in Bacan islands group; Halmahera Utara regency, Galela bay, east of Galela town; Pulau Morotai regency, Rau and Morotai islands.
Galela.population: 79,000 (1990 SIL). 41,000 Kadai, 10,000 Kadina, 24,000 Morotai, and 4,000 Sopi.

Tanahmerah.name: Tanahmerah
Tanahmerah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tanahmerah
Tanahmerah.location: Papua Barat province: Teluk Bintuni regency on north Bomberai peninsula, Bintuni bay, Bapai and Gondu river areas.

Batak Alas-Kluet.name: Batak Alas-Kluet
Batak Alas-Kluet.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Batak, Northern
Batak Alas-Kluet.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batak Alas-Kluet
Batak Alas-Kluet.dialects: Alas, Kluet, Singkil (Kade-Kade). Alas dialect may be more similar to Karo Batak
Batak Alas-Kluet.other_comments: Many reject the label Batak for its cultural connotations. Unclear whether this is a single language.
Batak Alas-Kluet.location: Aceh province: inland from Tapaktuan, and northwest towards Kutacane; into Sumatera Utara province.
Batak Alas-Kluet.population: 195,000 (2000 census). Includes 80,000 Alas, 50,000 Kluet, and 65,000 Singkil.

Bayono.name: Bayono
Bayono.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bayono
Bayono.dialects: None known. Not related to language families like Ok, Asmat, Awyu-Dumut, Momuna, or highlands language families like Dani or Mek. Lexical similarity: 55% with Awbono
Bayono.location: Papua province: Asmat regency, Eilanden-Steenboom river area.

Pannei.name: Pannei
Pannei.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Pitu Ulunna Salu
Pannei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pannei
Pannei.dialects: Tapango, Bulo. Lexical similarity: 87%–93% between the Bulo dialect and other varieties, 75%–80% with dialects of Ulumanda’
Pannei.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Polewali Mandar regency, Wonomulyo sub-district.

Sarudu.name: Sarudu
Sarudu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sarudu
Sarudu.dialects: Nunu’, Kulu (Lariang). Lexical similarity: 75% with Uma
Sarudu.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Mamuju Utara regency, south Pasangkayu sub-district, 1 area near Lariang river mouth, another south, both on Makassar strait north coast.

Bulungan.name: Bulungan
Bulungan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bulungan
Bulungan.dialects: May be a dialect of Southern Tidung
Bulungan.location: Kalimantan Timur province: Tanjungselor town area, lower Kayan river.

Saparua.name: Saparua
Saparua.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Uliase, Hatuhaha, Saparua
Saparua.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Saparua
Saparua.dialects: Kulur, Iha-Saparua, Iha-Seram, Siri-Sori. Each village has its own dialect. Lexical similarity: 86%–89% among dialects; 82%–84% with Latu
Saparua.language_use: Shifting to Ambon Malay [abs] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Latu [ltu].
Saparua.location: Maluku province: Hualoy, Iha, Kairatu, Kulur, Latu, Siri-Sori, Tomalehu villages; Saparua and Seram islands.

Bauzi.name: Bauzi
Bauzi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bauzi
Bauzi.other_comments: Whistle speech reported. Christian, traditional religion.
Bauzi.language_use: Vigorous. Some Aliki speak Bauzi [bvz] due to intermarriage and trading. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Eritai [ert], Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Eritai [ert].
Bauzi.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–25%. 230 can read and write it. NT: 2008.
Bauzi.location: Papua province: Jayapura and Yapen Waropen regencies, Mamberamo Tengah and Waropen Atas sub-districts, Danau Bira, Itaba, Kustera, Neao, Noiadi, Solom, and Vakiadi villages; extensive inland area between Mamberamo and Rouffaer rivers.

Ma\u2019anyan.name: Ma’anyan
Ma\u2019anyan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, East, Central-South, South
Ma\u2019anyan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ma’anyan
Ma\u2019anyan.dialects: Samihim (Buluh Kuning), Sihong (Siong), Dusun Balangan. Related to Malagasy languages in Madagascar. Lexical similarity: 77% with Paku
Ma\u2019anyan.location: Kalimantan Selatan province: border area, and 2 areas near Damar and Tawahan; Kalimantan Tengah province: Barito Selatan and Barito Timur regencies, Awang, Dusun Hilir, Dusun Selatan, Dusun Tengah, Dusun Utara, Gunung Bintang Awai, Karau Kuala, and Patangkep Tutui sub-districts, south Tamianglayang town area.

Watubela.alt_name: Esiriun, Kasiui, Kasui, Kesui, Matabello, Snabi Watubela, Wesi
Watubela.name: Watubela
Watubela.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Banda-Geser, Geser-Gorom
Watubela.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Watubela
Watubela.dialects: Tamher Timur, Sulmelang. Lexical similarity: 77% between dialects, 51%–61% with Geser-Gorom
Watubela.location: Maluku province: Watubela islands east central area.

Malay, Papuan.status: 3 (Wider communication). LWC in the coastal areas of West Papua. Became an LWC mostly as a result of Dutch colonial language policies in the early 20th century, and before that, to a rather limited extent, through trade (Kluge 2014:11–15).
Malay, Papuan.name: Malay, Papuan
Malay, Papuan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Papuan
Malay, Papuan.dialects: North Papua Malay, Serui Malay, Bird’s Head Malay, South Coast Malay. Reportedly similar to both Ambonese Malay
Malay, Papuan.language_use: Growing number of L1 speakers, who express a strong preference for their Malay variety over Indonesian [ind] or other regional varieties. All domains except formal government settings or formal education. Used unofficially in many school settings. All ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Ambel [wgo], Beneraf [bnv], Berik [bkl], Betaf [bfe], Bonggo [bpg], Dabe [dbe], Dao [daz], Dineor [mrx], Emem [enr], Fedan [pdn], Jofotek-Bromnya [jbr], Kaptiau [kbi], Kayagar [kyt], Kimki [sbt], Kirikiri [kiy], Kowiai [kwh], Kwinsu [kuc], Liki [lio], Mawes [mgk], Mo [wkd], Morori [mok], Nakai [nkj], Namla [naa], Nimboran [nir], Orya [ury], Skou [skv], Sobei [sob], Sowari [dmy], Sunum [ymn], Tangko [tkx], Tarpia [tpf], Tebi [dmu], Tobati [tti], Towei [ttn], Usku [ulf], Viid [snu], Vitou [vto], Warembori [wsa], Yei [jei], Zorop [wfg].
Malay, Papuan.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 67% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua province; 94% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua Barat province (2010 census). Officially no data on L1 literacy are available. Those literate in Indonesian [ind] can read and write Papuan Malay. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Yayasan Betania Indonesia.
Malay, Papuan.typology: SVO, elision of arguments is common; 18 consonant and 5 vowel phonemes, disyllabic roots preferred, CV and CVC syllables preferred, maximal syllable is CCVC, typically penultimate syllable is stressed. Inflectional morphology is lacking; word formation is limited to reduplication which is very productive and affixation (limited productivity). Open word classes are nouns, verbs, and adverbs; closed classes are personal pronouns, interrogatives, demonstratives, locatives, numerals, quantifiers, prepositions, and conjunctions. Prepositions; clause final question particle.

Murut, Tahol.name: Murut, Tahol
Murut, Tahol.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, Sabahan, Murutic, Murut
Murut, Tahol.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Murut, Tahol

Reportedly most similar to Paluan
Murut, Tahol.language_use: The Tahol language seems to be widely used, even among young people. Home, Friends, Religion, Work; Mixed use: Education. Some children; all adults and elderly. Positive attitudes. Most also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Some also use Standard Malay [zsm]. A few also use English [eng], Hakka Chinese [hak], Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Timugon Murut [tih]. Used as L2 by Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Keningau Murut [kxi], Kolod Murut [kqv], Paluan Murut [plz], Selungai Murut [slg], Timugon Murut [tih].
Murut, Tahol.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Standard Malay [zsm]. A school for older adults has been set up to teach them to read in Murut Tahol. The primary reviewers expressed the need for primary and secondary school language subjects in Tahol Murut (like Kadazan Dusun), since this is the largest Murutic language in Sabah. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1998. Agency: Sabah Murut Cultural Association, Kadazandusun Language Foundation (KLF).
Murut, Tahol.location: Sabah: Nabawan district, south Sipitang and Tenom districts, mainly along Maligan, Padas (Tomani), Salalir, Tahol, Tolokoson, and watersheds. Sarawak: Lawas district.
Murut, Tahol.population: 20,000 (2015 L. Murang), decreasing. Ethnic population: 200,000 (2015 L. Murang). Largest Murutic group in Sabah (Harris 1991; Brewis 2004: 43). Total users in all countries: 22,000.

Banda.name: Banda

Towei.name: Towei
Towei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Towei
Towei.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy], Yetfa [yet].
Towei.location: Papua province: Pegunungan Bintang regency, Towe Hitam village.

Edopi.alt_name: Dosobou, Dou, Doufou, Elopi, Foi, Iau, Turu, Urundi, Ururi, Yau

Edopi.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Kirikiri [kiy].

Baham.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, West Bomberai, West Bomberai Proper

Diuwe.name: Diuwe
Diuwe.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Diuwe
Diuwe.location: Papua province: Asmat regency, southeast of Wamena city.

Enrekang.name: Enrekang
Enrekang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Masenrempulu
Enrekang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Enrekang
Enrekang.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Enrekang and Pinrang regencies, Enrekang town area, west toward Mandar bay head; Sulawesi Barat province: Polewali Mandar regency coastal area.

Alor.name: Alor

Bahau.name: Bahau
Bahau.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Kayan Proper
Bahau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bahau
Bahau.location: Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai Barat regency, Long Apari, Long Bagun, and Long Hubung, and Long Pahangai sub-districts; Ratah and Mahakam rivers’ confluence area.

Roma.name: Roma

Kanum, Ngk\u00e2lmpw.name: Kanum, Ngkâlmpw

Chinese, Hakka.alt_name: Hokka, Ke, Kechia, Kejia, Majiahua, Tu Guangdonghua, Xinminhua

Maklew.name: Maklew
Maklew.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Maklew
Maklew.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Yelmek
Maklew.location: Papua province: Merauke regency; south coast area.

Bunak.name: Bunak
Bunak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bunak
Bunak.dialects: None known. Not closely related to other languages.
Bunak.other_comments: Small groups scattered among other languages. Traditional religion, Christian.
Bunak.location: Ainaro district: Zumalai subdistrict; Bobonaro district: Maliana south; Cova Lima district: on Timor island central interior, south coast, north of Suai town.

Embaloh.alt_name: Malo, Maloh, Matoh, Mbaloh, Memaloh, Palin, Pari, Sangau, Sanggau

Yali, Angguruk.name: Yali, Angguruk

Bedoanas.name: Bedoanas

Bedoanas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bedoanas

Bedoanas.location: Papua Barat province: Fakfak regency, Kokas sub-district; Bomberai peninsula.

Pekal.name: Pekal
Pekal.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pekal
Pekal.other_comments: See themselves as Malay culturally and linguistically, not Minangkabau
Pekal.language_use: Vigorous. Home, village. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], for civics and religion.
Pekal.location: Sumatera Selatan and Bengkulu provinces: northeast of Ipuh town to Tembesi river, to Argamakmur area south.

Duriankere.name: Duriankere
Duriankere.classification: Trans-New Guinea, South Bird’s Head, Inanwatan
Duriankere.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Duriankere
Duriankere.language_use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Elderly speakers.

Citak.alt_name: Asmat Darat, Cicak, Kaunak, Tjitak, Tjitjak
Citak.name: Citak
Citak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Citak
Citak.dialects: Senggo, Komasma, Bubis, Esaun, Pirabanak, Vakam, Tiau. Reportedly similar to Asmat

Dera.name: Dera
Dera.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dera
Dera.location: Papua province: Keerom regency, 13 villages on Papua New Guinea border.
Dera.population: 1,000 (1987 SIL). Total users in all countries: 1,690.

Panasuan.name: Panasuan

Aoheng.name: Aoheng
Aoheng.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Muller-Schwaner ‘Punan’
Aoheng.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Aoheng
Aoheng.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 69% with Kereho
Aoheng.location: Kalimantan Timur province: Sarawak border area, upper reaches of Barito, Kapuas, and Mahakam rivers; Kalimantan Tengah province: border areas.

Tomini.name: Tomini
Tomini.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Northern
Tomini.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tomini
Tomini.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Parigi Moutong and Toli-Toli regencies; Gorontalo province: Pohuwato regency, east to Mautang area. 42 villages.

Mapia.name: Mapia

Mapia.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mapia
Mapia.location: Papua Barat province: Manokwari regency, Mapia islands.

Mander.name: Mander
Mander.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mander
Mander.language_use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home. Adults only. Also use Berik [bkl].
Mander.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, 2 areas on upper Tor river tributary of upper Bu river.

Munggui.name: Munggui

Malay, Kota Bangun Kutai.name: Malay, Kota Bangun Kutai

Malay, Kota Bangun Kutai.dialects: Not intelligible with mainstream Tenggarong Kutai Malay

Woi.name: Woi
Woi.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, Central-Western
Woi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Woi
Woi.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 77% with Pom
Woi.location: Papua province: west Yapen island, Wooi and Wainap villages.

Awyu, South.alt_name: Jenimu, Oser, Siagha, Sjiagha, Syiagha, Yenimu
Awyu, South.name: Awyu, South

Kisar.name: Kisar

Kisar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kisar

Kisar.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Luang [lex], Oirata [oia].
Kisar.location: Maluku province: south, over 20 villages; Kisar island, northeast of Timor island, 19 villages; Roma and Wetar islands, Amau, Hila, Hi’ai, Likagraha, and Naumatan villages; some in Ambon, Dili, and Kupang cities.

Biga.name: Biga

Biga.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Biga
Biga.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong district, Biga village.

Musi.status: 3 (Wider communication). Much of the population from other language groups in South Sumatra Province learn enough Urban Palembang dialect to use it as a trade language.

Musi.location: Sumatera Selatan province: widespread in northern 2 thirds of province from Musi river upstream to Bukit Barisan mountains, downstream to coastal swamplands; Lampung province: northeast; border areas in Jambi and Bengkulu provinces.

Dineor.name: Dineor
Dineor.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dineor
Dineor.dialects: None known. Unintelligible to speakers in neighboring settlements including Bonggo.
Dineor.language_use: Only eleven families live in Tarawasi-Maremgi village, the only place Dineor (Marenggi) language is spoken. Home. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].

Roon.name: Roon

Roon.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Roon
Roon.location: Papua Barat province: Roon island west of Cenderawasih bay.

Kei.name: Kei
Kei.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Southeast Maluku, Kei-Tanimbar, Kei-Fordata
Kei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kei
Kei.dialects: Kei Kecil, Kei Besar, Tayando, Tanimbar Kei (Atnebar), Ta’am. Kei Kecil is the prestigious urban dialect. Kei Besar speakers usually also know Kei Kecil, but not vice versa. Kei Besar is reportedly more similar to Fordata
Kei.language_use: Fairly vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Banda [bnd], Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Banda [bnd], Kur [kuv].
Kei.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 100 can read, 10 can write. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 100 can read, 10 can write. Used informally in school for explanations. Dictionary. Grammar.

Malay, Manado.status: 3 (Wider communication). An important, growing lingua franca in many parts of Sulawesi.

Waru.name: Waru

Waru.language_use: Under pressure from larger neighboring languages and from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Waru.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Konawe Utara regency, Asera sub-district interior, Mopute village.

Kwesten.name: Kwesten
Kwesten.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kwesten
Kwesten.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 40% with Berik
Kwesten.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Arare, Holmhaven, Mafenter, and Omte villages in Pacific coast area.

Kapauri.name: Kapauri
Kapauri.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kapauri
Kapauri.language_use: Endangered to seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Most domains.
Kapauri.location: Papua province: Pagai village, Kamikaru and Magri hamlets on upper Idenburg river north bank.

Waris.name: Waris
Waris.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Waris
Waris.dialects: None known. Intelligible at Imonda but not Amanab. Similar to Imonda
Waris.language_use: Vigorous. Most domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Daonda [dnd].
Waris.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught in primary schools, in many villages. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2003.
Waris.location: Sandaun province: Amanab district, Wasengla area.
Waris.population: 2,500, increasing. Total users in all countries: 4,000.

Malay, Jambi.name: Malay, Jambi
Malay, Jambi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Jambi
Malay, Jambi.dialects: Downstream Jambi Malay, Upstream Jambi Malay. Forms a network of related varieties with Minangkabau
Malay, Jambi.language_use: As with many Malay varieties, gradually becoming more like Indonesian [ind]. Home, village. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Malay, Jambi.location: Bengkulu province: small area south of Lake Dipatipan; Jambi province: widespread; Riau province: Indragiri Hulu and Indragiri Hilir regencies; Sumatera Barat province: Pessisir Selantan regency border enclave; Sumatera Selatan province: northern border area; all on southeast Sumatra island.

Kereho.name: Kereho

Kereho.location: Kalimantan Barat province: east Kapuas Hulu regency; Kalimantan Tengah province: Murung Raya regency; Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai Barat regency.

Muyu, South.alt_name: Digoel, Digul, Kati Metomka, Metomka, Moejoe, Ok Bari, South Kati, Yonggom, Yongkom, Yongom

Ibu.name: Ibu

Ibu.dialects: None known. May be inherently intelligible with Sahu
Ibu.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera Barat regency, Gamlamo and Gamici villages on north Halmahera island, Iboe river mouth.
Ibu.population: 35 (Voorhoeve and Visser 1987). In 1987, there were a few elderly speakers but it is now probably extinct (Wurm 2007). Ethnic population: 50 (1984).

Sowari.name: Sowari

Kemberano.name: Kemberano

Banjar.status: 3 (Wider communication). Banjar became a LWC through trade. LWC in the market, in business, and in media. Banjar, already dominant in South Kalimantan Province, is also growing rapidly in Central and Eastern Kalimantan provinces.
Banjar.name: Banjar
Banjar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Banjar
Banjar.dialects: Kuala, Hulu. Lexically influenced by Javanese
Banjar.location: Kalimantan Selatan province: Banjarmasin area; Kalimantan Tengah province: Palangkaraya, Pangkalanbun, and Sampit; Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai, Pasir, and Pulau Laut coastal regions, north toward Samarinda city and Mahakan delta; Kalimantan Barat province: some in coastal Matua; Kalimantan south and southeastern coasts, Java Sea and Makassar Strait.
Banjar.population: 3,500,000 (2000 census), increasing. Total users in all countries: 3,505,000.

Kodi.name: Kodi
Kodi.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Sumba-Hawu, Sumba
Kodi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kodi
Kodi.dialects: Kodi Bokol, Kodi Bangedo, Nggaro (Nggaura). May be most similar to Wejewa
Kodi.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: west Sumba.

Tulehu.name: Tulehu
Tulehu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Ambon

Kepo\u2019.name: Kepo’
Kepo\u2019.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kepo’
Kepo\u2019.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Manggarai Timur regency, 2 areas in central Flores island highlands.

Ketengban.name: Ketengban
Ketengban.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ketengban
Ketengban.dialects: Okbap, Omban, Bime, Onya. Lexical similarity: 69% with Una
Ketengban.language_use: All domains. Used as L2 by Lepki [lpe].
Ketengban.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%. Dictionary. NT: 1997–2013.
Ketengban.location: Papua province: Papua New Guinea border area, east highland slopes, scattered.

Una.name: Una

Jofotek-Bromnya.name: Jofotek-Bromnya

Demisa.location: Papua province: Waropen Bawah sub-district, Botawa, Desawa, and Muyere villages; inland in northeast Canderawasih bay.

Pamona.name: Pamona

Barapasi.name: Barapasi

Iha Based Pidgin.name: Iha Based Pidgin

Punan Merap.name: Punan Merap

Punan Merap.location: Kalimantan Utara province: Malinau regency on upper Malinau river.

Tolaki.population: 331,000 (2000 census). 298,000 Tolaki (Konawe), 33,000 Mekongga and 200 Wiwirano. Asera and Laiwui not separately listed, but less than 1,000.

Putoh.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Putoh

Chinese, Min Nan.name: Chinese, Min Nan

Chao-Shan has difficult intelligibility with Amoy; Hainan quite different from other dialects and mutually unintelligible with Hokkien and Teochew. Most speakers in Thailand use Chaoshou dialect. Tamagario.name: Tamagario

Duri.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Masenrempulu
Duri.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Duri
Duri.language_use: Vigorous. Prestige language of the Masenrempulu group.
Duri.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: north Enrekang regency; Makassar city and other communities.

Konjo, Highland.name: Konjo, Highland
Konjo, Highland.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Konjo, Highland
Konjo, Highland.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 75% with Coastal Konjo
Konjo, Highland.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Bone, Bulukumba, Gowa, and Sinjai regencies, south peninsula interior; Mount Lompobatang area northwest, past Makassar city.

Kayupulau.name: Kayupulau
Kayupulau.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Jayapura Bay
Kayupulau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kayupulau
Kayupulau.language_use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Mainly adults 50 and older.
Kayupulau.location: Papua province: Kota Jayapura city and island in Jayapura harbor.
Kayupulau.population: 50 (Wurm 2000). Used by under 10% of the ethnic group (Wurm 2007).

Mandobo Bawah.name: Mandobo Bawah
Mandobo Bawah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mandobo Bawah
Mandobo Bawah.location: Papua province: Boven Digul regency, Aiwat, Anggai, Butiptiri, Getentiri, Kaisah, and Subur villages; south of Tanahmerah and Mindiptanah towns, to Fly river on Papua New Guinea border.

Maba.name: Maba
Maba.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, South Halmahera, Southeast
Maba.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Maba
Maba.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].
Maba.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera island, Wasilei area on southeast peninsula, north coast facing Buli bay.

Sangir.name: Sangir
Sangir.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sangir
Sangir.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Great Sangir island east peninsula.
Sangir.population: 200,000 (Maryott 1993), increasing. 50,000 Siau, 10,000 Tagulandang. Total users in all countries: 255,000.

Gane.name: Gane
Gane.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, South Halmahera, East Makian-Gane
Gane.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Gane
Gane.dialects: Reportedly similar to Kayoa, a dialect of East Makian
Gane.language_use: Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].
Gane.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera island, south peninsula.

Taloki.name: Taloki
Taloki.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Eastern, East Coast, Kulisusu
Taloki.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Taloki
Taloki.language_use: Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Also use Muna [mnb] (Wurm 2007).
Taloki.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Buton Utara regency; Kapontori and Wakorumba sub-districts, Maligano and Wakalambe villages on Buton island northwest coast.
Taloki.population: 550 (2005 R. Van den Berg). 400 in Maligano, 150 in Wakalambe.

Kowiai.alt_name: Adi, Aiduma, Kaiwai, Kajumerah, Kayumerah, Koiwai, Kuiwai, Namatota, Namatote
Kowiai.name: Kowiai
Kowiai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Bomberai
Kowiai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kowiai
Kowiai.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm) but also not endangered. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Mairasi [zrs].
Kowiai.location: Papua Barat province: Kaimana regency, Adijaya, Kayumerah, Keroi, and Namatota villages; Bomberai peninsula, Kamrau bay area, Kaimana, Namatote, and Adi islands, smaller islands in bay.

Bobongko.name: Bobongko
Bobongko.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Saluan-Banggai, Western, Saluanic
Bobongko.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bobongko
Bobongko.other_comments: Bobongko is not derogatory to its speakers, but it is to the Andio
Bobongko.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Batu Daka island, Tumbulawa village on northwest coast; Togian islands, Lembanato village on Kilat bay, north side of Togian island.

Latu.name: Latu
Latu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Uliase, Hatuhaha, Saparua
Latu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Latu
Latu.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Barat regency, Latu village; west Seram island, southwest Elpaputih bay, Point Latu.

Puragi.name: Puragi
Puragi.classification: Trans-New Guinea, South Bird’s Head, South Bird’s Head Proper, Western
Puragi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Puragi
Puragi.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong Selatan regency on southwest Bird’s Head along Maccluer Gulf, Matamani river area, and inland.

Geser-Gorom.alt_name: Gesa, Geser, Goram, Goran, Gorom, Gorong, Seram, Seran, Seran Laut
Geser-Gorom.name: Geser-Gorom
Geser-Gorom.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Banda-Geser, Geser-Gorom
Geser-Gorom.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Geser-Gorom
Geser-Gorom.dialects: Goram Laut, Mina Mina Gorong, Kelimuri. Lexical similarity: 73%–93% among dialects, 51%–61% with Watubela
Geser-Gorom.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Fordata [frd], in a few villages. Used as L2 by Bati [bvt], Masiwang [bnf], Watubela [wah].

Batak Simalungun.name: Batak Simalungun
Batak Simalungun.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Batak, Simalungan
Batak Simalungun.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batak Simalungun
Batak Simalungun.location: Sumatera Utara province: Deli Serdang, Kota Pematang Siantar, Serdang Bedagai, and Simalungun regencies.

Jangkang.name: Jangkang
Jangkang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Jangkang
Jangkang.location: Kalimantan Barat province: central Sanggau regency, between Sanggau and Balai Sebut towns on Kapuas river tributary.

Sanggau.name: Sanggau
Sanggau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sanggau
Sanggau.dialects: Dosan, Mayau, Sanggau. Very heterogenous dialects, probably more than 1 language in this group. Not all Sanggau isolects mutually intelligible. Koman and Semerawai could be in this group.
Sanggau.location: Kalimantan Barat province: Sanggau regency along Kapuas river.

Sasak.name: Sasak
Sasak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sasak
Sasak.dialects: Kuto-Kute (North Sasak), Ngeto-Ngete (Northeast Sasak), Meno-Mene (Central Sasak), Ngeno-Ngene (Central East Sasak, Central West Sasak), Mriak-Mriku (Central South Sasak). Complex dialect network. Some varieties have low mutual intelligibility.
Sasak.other_comments: Subgroups: Waktu Lima, Waktu Telu. Most Waktu Telu own farms; most Waktu Lima are landless, travel more, and have diverse occupations. Muslim, traditional religion.
Sasak.location: Nusa Tenggara Barat province: Lombok island.

Rejang.name: Rejang
Rejang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Rejang
Rejang.dialects: Lebong, Kepahiang (Kebanagung), Pasisir, Musi (Curup), Rawas. Lebong recognized as central dialect.
Rejang.other_comments: 85% live in remote rural areas. Different from Rejang-Baram group of languages on Borneo. Musi and Rawas dialects (named after rivers they are on) not to be confused with Malay varieties of the same name. Muslim.
Rejang.language_use: Vigorous. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], but with low bilingualism.
Rejang.location: Bengkulu province: Arga Makmur, Curup, Kapahiang, and Muara Aman town areas in southwest highlands; Sumatera Selatan province: Musi Rawas Ulu, west.

Ndom.name: Ndom
Ndom.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ndom
Ndom.dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Kimaghima

Huaulu.name: Huaulu
Huaulu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Manusela-Seti
Huaulu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Huaulu
Huaulu.other_comments: Culturally distinct from Sou Upaa. Traditional religion.
Huaulu.location: Maluku province: Maluku Tengah regency, 10 villages on north Seram island, Salemen bay, south end near Opin town.

Taikat.name: Taikat
Taikat.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Taikat
Taikat.dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Awyi
Taikat.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under strong pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Taikat.location: Papua province: northeast border area south of Jayapura.

Kumbewaha.name: Kumbewaha
Kumbewaha.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Buton, East Buton
Kumbewaha.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kumbewaha
Kumbewaha.language_use: All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Lasalimu [llm], Tukang Besi North [khc], Tukang Besi South [bhq].
Kumbewaha.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Buton regency, Lasalimu sub-district, Kumbewaha and Wajah Jaya villages on southeast Buton island.

Dobel.name: Dobel
Dobel.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dobel
Dobel.dialects: Northern Dobel, Straits Dobel, Southeast Dobel. At least 3 dialects. Lexical similarity: 78%–86% with Koba
Dobel.language_use: Vigorous. Some Chinese merchants who speak Dobo Malay dialect of Ambonese Malay [abs] and older Hokkien [nan] learn Dobel. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Manombai [woo]. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], specifically the Dobo Malay dialect. Nearly all school-age speakers of Dobel are bilingual in this variety. Used as L2 by Lorang [lrn], Manombai [woo].
Dobel.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literature. Bible portions: 1991–2009.
Dobel.location: Maluku province: Kepulauan Aru regency, Aru islands; Kobror island central and east coast, 18 villages; southeast Wokam island, 1 village; 4 villages in east Barakai strait on Kobror and Koba islands; 2 villages south of Beding Warlai town; many in Dobo; some in Ambon.
Dobel.typology: SVO; prepositions; no adjectives; noun head initial; active verbs and stative verbs; complex reduplication system; 14 consonant phonemes and 5 vowel phonemes; CVC, CV, with CiCiVC, CiCiV patterns occurring only as stressed syllable of a phonological word, when that word is reduplicated; not tonal.

Tefaro.name: Tefaro
Tefaro.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tefaro
Tefaro.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 61% with Barapasi
Tefaro.location: Papua province: Demba and Tefaro villages in east Cenderawasih bay.

Seko Tengah.name: Seko Tengah
Seko Tengah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Seko Tengah
Seko Tengah.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 71% with Seko Padang
Seko Tengah.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: west Limbong sub-district along Betue river.

Kwerba Mamberamo.alt_name: Napok, Nobuk, Nogukwabai, Nopuk, Nopukw, Tatsewalem
Kwerba Mamberamo.name: Kwerba Mamberamo
Kwerba Mamberamo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kwerba Mamberamo
Kwerba Mamberamo.other_comments: ‘Nopukw’, language, in the Kwerba family, and does not distinguish a particular variety. Traditional religion, Christian.
Kwerba Mamberamo.location: Papua province: Edifalen, Kwerba, and Marinafalen villages on Mamberamo river east bank and into highlands.

Wolio.name: Wolio
Wolio.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Wolio
Wolio.other_comments: ‘Buton’ usually used generically inside Southeast Sulawesi to refer to Wolio; outside Southeast Sulawesi it refers to people from Southeast Sulawesi, or is sometimes confused with Bajau people as sailors. Muslim.
Wolio.language_use: Former court language of Baubau Sultanate, and surrounding communities; formerly used by nobility in the region. Wolio is declining in the urban center, but being maintained at the rural periphery. Children in villages use Wolio, but city children primarily use Indonesian. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Busoa [bup], Cia-Cia [cia], Liabuku [lix], Pancana [pnp], Tukang Besi South [bhq].
Wolio.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Buton regency, Kota Bau-Bau city on Buton island southwest coast.
Wolio.population: 65,000 (2004 D. Andersen). Population does not include those in other provinces.

Kata Kolok.alt_name: Bengkala Sign Language, Benkala Sign Language
Kata Kolok.name: Kata Kolok
Kata Kolok.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kata Kolok
Kata Kolok.other_comments: In the linguistic literature, the language is referred to as Kata Kolok, which means ‘deaf language’ in Balinese
Kata Kolok.language_use: Vigorous, by both deaf and hearing. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Many also use Bali [ban], especially in the village and among hearing native signers, who are fully bilingual (Marsaja 2008). Some also use Indonesian Sign Language [inl], which has been acquired in boarding schools in Singaraja and Jimbaran by about 8 deaf teenagers (de Vos 2016).
Kata Kolok.language_development: Starting 2007, a local elementary school uses Kata Kolok as a language of instruction in special math and literacy sections for deaf students (de Vos 2012). Taught in primary schools.
Kata Kolok.location: Java and Bali provinces: Bali island, Buleleng regency, Bengkala village (Desa Kolok deaf village).

Mor.name: Mor
Mor.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mor
Mor.language_use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Baham [bdw], Iha [ihp], and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home. Used by few or no children.
Mor.location: Papua Barat province: Fakfak regency on northwest Bomberai peninsula, Berau bay inland.

Imroing.name: Imroing
Imroing.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Babar, South, Southwest Babar
Imroing.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Imroing
Imroing.language_use: Shifting to a local Malay variety. Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], in all domains, except for ceremonies. Children are taught this variety. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.
Imroing.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency, Emroing village; Babar island southwest.

Ratahan.name: Ratahan
Ratahan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ratahan
Ratahan.language_use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Most are 60 and older.
Ratahan.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Minahasa regency on northeast peninsula and Tomini bay.

Meyah.alt_name: Arfak, Mansibaber, Meah, Meax, Mejach, Mejah, Meyach
Meyah.name: Meyah
Meyah.classification: East Bird’s Head-Sentani, East Bird’s Head, Meax
Meyah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Meyah
Meyah.dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Manikion
Meyah.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Meyah.location: Papua Barat province: Bird’s Head northeast coast.

Duano.alt_name: Desin Dolak, Desin Duano, Duano’, Orang Kuala
Duano.name: Duano
Duano.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Duano
Duano.location: Sumatra, Riau province: west archipelago and Daratan east coast; into Jambi province: northeast coast; Riau Province, Bengkalis, Kepulauan Meranti, and Pelawan regencies, offshore islands Rangsang, Mendol, and Bengkalis, 4 areas.
Duano.population: 15,000 (2006 SIL). Ethnic population: Total ethnic population all countries: 19,000 (2006 E. Seidlitz). Total users in all countries: 15,600.

Budong-Budong.name: Budong-Budong
Budong-Budong.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Seko, Panasuan
Budong-Budong.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Budong-Budong
Budong-Budong.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Aralle-Tabulahan
Budong-Budong.language_use: Some intermarriage and bilingualism with Topoiyo [toy] is pressuring vitality (Wurm 2007).
Budong-Budong.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Mamuju regency, Budong-Budong sub-district, Tongkou village; Makassar strait, Budong-Budong river area.

Chinese, Yue.status: 2 (Provincial). De facto provincial language in Guangdong Province. Language of recognized nationality: Han.
Chinese, Yue.alt_name: Cantonese, Yue, Yueh, Yuet Yue, Yueyu
Chinese, Yue.name: Chinese, Yue
Chinese, Yue.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Chinese, Yue
Chinese, Yue.dialects: Siyi (Hoisan, Schleiyip, Seiyap, Taishan, Toisan), Gaolei (Gaoyang), Qinlian, Guinan, Ping, Bobai, Tengxian, Cangwu, Yangjiang, Zhongshan, Guangzhou. The Guangzhou variety considered the standard. A member of macrolanguage Chinese
Chinese, Yue.other_comments: Many members of other nationalities in Guangxi, Guangdong and Hainan also speak Yue dialects.
Chinese, Yue.language_use: Second only to Mandarin [cmn] in use. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], which many understand, speaking it only with difficulty. Used as L2 by Biao [byk], Chadong [cdy], E [eee], Min Nan Chinese [nan], Vietnamese [vie], Yang Zhuang [zyg], Yongnan Zhuang [zyn], Zuojiang Zhuang [zzj].
Chinese, Yue.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Speakers are highly literate in Chinese. Taught in primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1894–1981.
Chinese, Yue.location: Guangdong province: most except Hakka-speaking areas northeast, and Min Nan-speaking areas east; Guangxi province: east; Hainan and Hunan provinces.
Chinese, Yue.typology: SVO; prepositions; genitives, relatives, adjectives, numerals before noun heads; noun classifiers; no articles; 18 consonants, 7 vowels; tonal (6 tones: 3 level, 3 contour).
Chinese, Yue.population: 62,000,000 (Asher and Moseley 2007). Total users in all countries: 72,893,210.

Dawera-Daweloor.name: Dawera-Daweloor
Dawera-Daweloor.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Babar, North
Dawera-Daweloor.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dawera-Daweloor
Dawera-Daweloor.language_use: Shifting to a local Malay variety. Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], in all domains, except for ceremonies; children are taught a regional variety. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.
Dawera-Daweloor.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency, Wiratan, Watuwei, and Nurnyaman villages in Banda Sea on twin coral islands northeast of Babar island; Daweloor island; Dawera island, Ilmarang, Letmasa, and Welora villages.

Kayan, Mendalam.name: Kayan, Mendalam
Kayan, Mendalam.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Kayan Proper
Kayan, Mendalam.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kayan, Mendalam
Kayan, Mendalam.location: Kalimantan Barat province: along Mendalam river.

Osing.name: Osing
Osing.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Osing
Osing.location: Jawa Timur province: Banyuwangi regency area on far east Java island facing Bali strait.

Ansus.name: Ansus
Ansus.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, Central-Western
Ansus.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ansus
Ansus.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 82% with Marau
Ansus.location: Papua province: Yapen Waropen regency, Yapen Barat sub-district, Aibondeni, Ansus, Kairawi, and Yenusi villages on Yapen island south coast.

Dabe.name: Dabe
Dabe.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dabe
Dabe.language_use: Home, with friends, in the gardens. Seldom used by young children. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Dabe.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Pantai Timur sub-district, Dabe village, Tor river valley north to coast.

Wawonii.name: Wawonii
Wawonii.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Eastern, East Coast
Wawonii.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Wawonii
Wawonii.dialects: Wawonii, Menui (Manoei). Lexical similarity: 75% with Bungku
Wawonii.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Wawonii and Menui islands near Kendari port.

Komyandaret.name: Komyandaret
Komyandaret.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Komyandaret
Komyandaret.dialects: None known. May be mutually intelligible with Tsaukambo
Komyandaret.location: Papua province: Sungai river west bank headwaters.

Fordata.alt_name: Larat, Vai Fordata, Vai Sera-Larat-Fordata, Vai Tnebar, Vaidida
Fordata.name: Fordata
Fordata.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Southeast Maluku, Kei-Tanimbar, Kei-Fordata
Fordata.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Fordata
Fordata.dialects: Fordata-Larat I, Fordata-Larat II, Molo (Molo-Maru), Sera (Seira). Sera is most divergent dialect. Lexical similarity: 68% with Kei
Fordata.other_comments: Primary schools in nearly every village, secondary schools for every 3 or 4 villages. Christian, Muslim.
Fordata.language_use: Vigorous. Some villages have few young people being spoken to in Fordata. All domains, though church context limited. Positive attitudes. All also use Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Bugis [bug], Geser-Gorom [ges].
Fordata.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 2,500 read; 1,500 can write. Taught in primary schools, as a subject. Taught in secondary schools, as a subject. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1996–2004.
Fordata.location: Maluku province: southeast, 30 villages; north archipelago on Fordata, Larat, and Molu-Maru islands; northwest, Yamdena island west coast, Seira island; also Jakarta, other cities.
Fordata.population: 50,000 (Marshall 2000). 25,000 in the language area and 25,000 elsewhere (Marshall 2000). Decreasing use in mixed language towns. 500 monolinguals.

Tabla.alt_name: Jakari, Tabi, Tanah Merah, Tanahmerah, Tepera
Tabla.name: Tabla
Tabla.classification: East Bird’s Head-Sentani, Sentani, Sentani Proper
Tabla.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tabla
Tabla.dialects: Yokari, Tepera, Yewena-Yongsu. Yokari dialect understood by other dialects at 80% to 95%, others have 95%–100% mutual intelligibility. Lexical similarity: 30% with Sentani
Tabla.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Bukia, Depapre, and Wari towns, and 13 villages on north coast.

Balaesang.name: Balaesang
Balaesang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Southern
Balaesang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Balaesang
Balaesang.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Donggala regency, Balaesang sub-district, Kamonji, Ketong, and Rano villages on Manimbayu peninsula.

Kombai.name: Kombai
Kombai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kombai
Kombai.dialects: Central Kombai, Tayan. Reportedly most similar to Wanggom
Kombai.location: Papua province: Asmat regency, between upper Wideman and Digul rivers.

Malay, Kupang.name: Malay, Kupang
Malay, Kupang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Kupang
Malay, Kupang.other_comments: Loanwords from several Rote and Chinese languages, Portuguese
Malay, Kupang.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Helong [heg], Lole [llg], Termanu [twu], Tii [txq].
Malay, Kupang.language_development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2007.
Malay, Kupang.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Kupang regency, Kupang city and Semau island; all on west Timor island.

Andio.name: Andio
Andio.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Saluan-Banggai, Western
Andio.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Andio
Andio.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 44% with Bobongko
Andio.language_use: Much influence from Indonesian [ind] and neighboring languages, Saluan [loe] and Balantak [blz] (Wurm 2007). Also use Balantak [blz].
Andio.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Lamala sub-district, Tangeban and Tauge villages, peninsula east tip area.

Wano.name: Wano
Wano.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Wano
Wano.dialects: East Wano, Central Wano, West Wano. Reportedly similar to Nggem
Wano.language_use: Under pressure from Western Dani [dnw] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Religious services, home, field, community, oral. Most ages. Negative attitudes. Little interest in language revival, low prestige, considered inferior to Western Dani [dnw] and Indonesian [ind]. Also use Dem [dem], Indonesian [ind], Moni [mnz], Western Dani [dnw]. Used as L2 by Duvle [duv].
Wano.location: Papua province: Puncak and Puncak Jaya regencies in central highlands area; Van Daalen river to upper Rouffaer river.
