Tausug.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Kalagan [kqe]. Used as L2 by Balangingih Sama [sse], Central Sama [sml], Chavacano [cbk], Mapun [sjm], Pangutaran Sama [slm], Southern Sama [ssb], Yakan [yka].
Tausug.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught in primary schools, in Sulu and Tawi-Tawi. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1985–2002. Agency: Anak-Sug Association.
Tausug.location: Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao: Sulu province, Jolo, in Sulu archipelago; Basilan province, Basilan island; Mimaropa region: Palawan province on Palawan island; Zamboanga Peninsula region: Zamboanga city and environs.
Tausug.population: 900,000 (2000 SIL), increasing. 250,000 monolinguals. Total users in all countries: 1,062,000.

Larike-Wakasihu.name: Larike-Wakasihu
Larike-Wakasihu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, West, Hoamoal
Larike-Wakasihu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Larike-Wakasihu
Larike-Wakasihu.dialects: Allang, Wakasihu, Larike. The western end of the Ambon dialect subgroup. Lexical similarity: 81% among Allang, and Larike, and Wakasihu dialects; 92% between Larike and Wakasihu; 68%–71% with Asilulu
Larike-Wakasihu.language_use: Vigorous use in Larike and Wakasihu, weak in Allang. Only older adults in Allang, Allang Asaude, Uraur, and Urusana still know Allang, but apparently do not use it. Younger generation prefers regional or national language. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Larike-Wakasihu.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Larike-Wakasihu.location: Maluku province: Maluku Tengah regency, Allang, Lai, Larike, Tapi, and Wakasihu villages on southwest Ambon island coast, Hitu peninsula.

Gorontalo.name: Gorontalo
Gorontalo.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Gorontalo-Mongondow, Gorontalic
Gorontalo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Gorontalo
Gorontalo.dialects: East Gorontalo, Gorontalo Kota, West Gorontalo (Kwandang), Tilamuta, Limboto (Limbotto).
Gorontalo.language_use: Noted shift to Indonesian [ind] in youth. Also use Balantak [blz], Indonesian [ind].
Gorontalo.location: Gorontalo province: widespread along both coasts; Sulawesi Utara province: Bolaang Mongondon Utare regency, northeast of Gorontalo city.

Bajau, Indonesian.alt_name: Badjaw, Badjo, Bajao, Bajo, Bayo, Gaj, Indonesian Bajaw, Orang Laut, Sama, Taurije’ne’
Bajau, Indonesian.name: Bajau, Indonesian
Bajau, Indonesian.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, Sama-Bajaw, Sulu-Borneo, Borneo Coast Bajaw
Bajau, Indonesian.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bajau, Indonesian
Bajau, Indonesian.dialects: Jampea, Same’, Matalaang, Sulamu, Kajoa, Roti, Jaya Bakti, Poso, Togian 1, Togian 2, Wallace.
Bajau, Indonesian.other_comments: Known as Bayo and Taurije’ne’ in the Makasar
Bajau, Indonesian.language_use: Vigorous in north Maluku and Southeast Sulawesi. Also use Balantak [blz], Indonesian [ind].
Bajau, Indonesian.location: Sulawesi island: widespread throughout north central area; Maluku Utara province: on Bacan, Kayoa, Obi, and Sula islands.
Bajau, Indonesian.population: 150,000 (Mead et al 2007). 5,000 or more in North Maluku (Grimes 1982), 8,000 to 10,000 in South Sulawesi (Grimes and Grimes 1987), 7,000 in North Sulawesi and Gorontalo, 36,000 in Central Sulawesi, 40,000 in Southeast Sulawesi (Mead et al 2007), and several thousand in Nusa Tenggara (Wurm and Hattori 1981, Verheijen 1986).

Nias.name: Nias
Nias.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Nias
Nias.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nias
Nias.dialects: North Nias (Gunung Sitoli), South Nias, West Nias, Northwest Nias, Central Nias.
Nias.other_comments: North dialect (particularly Gunung Sitoli) has high prestige and is a lingua franca in Nias. The South dialect (particularly Teluk Dalam variety) has lower prestige, especially in northern Nias, and is considered by many Nias speakers from other areas as unrefined. Christian.
Nias.language_use: Vigorous. Home, Community; Mixed use: Religion, Work, Education. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], but with limited proficiency.
Nias.location: Sumatera Utara province: Batu, Nias and Mursala islands. Alasa, Sirombu and Mandrehe (Northwest dialect); Gomo, and south in Teluk Dalam and Batu islands (Central dialect).

Tombulu.alt_name: Minahasa, Minhasa, Tombalu, Tombula, Tombulu’, Toumbulu
Tombulu.name: Tombulu
Tombulu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tombulu
Tombulu.dialects: Taratara, Tomohon. Reportedly most similar to Tondano
Tombulu.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Minahasa regency, Kota Tomohon city.

Uma.name: Uma
Uma.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Uma
Uma.dialects: Winatu (Northern Uma), Tobaku (Dompa, Ompa, Western Uma), Tolee’ (Eastern Uma), Kantewu (Central Uma), Southern Uma (Aria), Benggaulu (Bingkolu), Bana. Literature exists in Kantewu dialect, but many would prefer to read their own dialect.
Uma.language_use: Use vigorous in the Uma homeland. Kantewu is prestige dialect. Among those living outside (e.g., in Palu, Palolo, Gimpu), use is vigorous among adults. For those who move away as adults, Uma remains language of the home. For those who move away as children, half retain Uma as home language. Daily work, local administration, religious services. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Ledo Kaili [lew], Rampi [lje], Seko Padang [skx].
Uma.language_development: Taught in primary schools. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Uma.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Lariang river west bank area; Sulawesi Selatan province: north Luwu regency, enclave within Seko Padang
Uma.population: 20,000 (1990 M. Martens), increasing. 15,000 in the region, 5,000 outside (1990 SIL), 500 in Benggaulu.

Waritai.name: Waritai
Waritai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Waritai
Waritai.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Waritai.location: Papua province: Tolikara regency; Taiyeve area south of Idenburg, Mamberama, and Rouffaer rivers’ confluence.

Hoti.name: Hoti
Hoti.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, East Seram
Hoti.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Hoti
Hoti.population: No known L1 speakers (Wurm 2007). 10 elderly speakers in 1987, but now probably extinct (Wurm 2007).

Indonesian.name: Indonesian
Indonesian.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Indonesian
Indonesian.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: over 80% with Standard Malay
Indonesian.other_comments: Developed from literary ‘Classical Malay’ of the Riau-Johor sultanate (Sneddon 2003). Has regional variants. Muslim.
Indonesian.typology: SVO; prepositions; noun head initial, but quantifiers before noun; 3 noun classifiers; no articles; aspect; 19 consonants, 6 vowels, 3 diphthongs; non-tonal; stress on penultimate syllable; 2 social registers; inclusive/exclusive pronouns.
Indonesian.population: 198,000,000 in Indonesia (2010 census), all users. 22,800,000 (2000), increasing. Total users in all countries: 198,395,070 (as L1: 23,195,070; as L2: 175,200,000).

Balantak.name: Balantak
Balantak.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Saluan-Banggai, Eastern
Balantak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Balantak
Balantak.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 66% with Andio
Balantak.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Andio [bzb], Bugis [bug], Gorontalo [gor], Indonesian Bajau [bdl].
Balantak.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2010.
Balantak.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Banggai regency, Balantak, Lamala, Luwuk, and Tinangkung Lamala sub-districts, at least 49 villages; Cape Talabu.
Balantak.population: 31,000, all users. 30,000 (2000 SIL), increasing. 1,000 (2015 R. Busenitz). 1,500 monolinguals (2015 R. Busenitz).

Mori Bawah.alt_name: Beneden-Tomori, East Mori, Lower Mori, Nahina, Oost-Mori, Petasia
Mori Bawah.name: Mori Bawah
Mori Bawah.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Eastern, East Coast
Mori Bawah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mori Bawah
Mori Bawah.dialects: Tinompo (Mokole, Soroako), Watu (Towatoe), Moiki (Tomoiki), Tiu (Tioe), Karunsi’e (Karonsie, Korongsi, Sinongko), Nuha (Soroako). Lexical similarity: 73%–86% with Mori Atas
Mori Bawah.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Bungku Tengah, Lembo, and Petasia sub-districts, 24 villages; Sulawesi Selatan province: Mahalone and Matano lakes. All locations are on southeast Sulawesi island peninsula, Lake Towuti area.

Malayic Dayak.name: Malayic Dayak
Malayic Dayak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malayic Dayak
Malayic Dayak.dialects: Tapitn, Banana’, Kayung (Kayong), Delang, Semitau, Suhaid, Mentebah-Suruk, Arut (Sukarame), Lamandau (Landau Kantu), Sukamara (Kerta Mulya), Riam (Nibung Terjung), Belantikan (Sungkup), Tamuan, Tomun, Pangin, Sekakai, Silat, Melahui, Serawai, Tebidah, Payak, Undau. Listed dialects form a chain and may constitute 3 or more languages. Related to Keninjal
Malayic Dayak.other_comments: Serawai dialect different from the Serawai dialect of Central Malay
Malayic Dayak.location: Widely dispersed; Kalimantan Tengah province: Katingan, Kotawaringgin Barat, Koti Timur, Lamandau, and Sukamara regencies; Kalimantan Barat province: small area near Sintang, area near Putussibau, and Sandai area, all along Kapuas river; Ketapang city northeast towards Kotabaru. Sandai, Muarakayang, Pembuanghulu, Sukamara, and Sukaraja town areas (Kayung and Delang dialects); Sintang to Putus Sibau town areas (Semitau, Suhaid, and Mentebah-Suruk dialects); Singakawang, Bengkayang, Darit, and Sungairaya town areas (Banana’ and Tapitn dialects); Muarakayang, Pembuanghulu, Sandai, Sukamara, and Sukaraja town areas (Kayung and Delang dialects).
Malayic Dayak.population: 520,000 (Wurm and Hattori 1981). 300 Tapitn, 100,000 Banana’, 100,000 Kayung, 200,000 Delang, 10,000 Semitau, 10,000 Suhaid, 20,000 Mentebah-Suruk.

Ili\u2019uun.alt_name: Erai, Hahutan, Hahutau, Iliun, Ilmaumau, Limera
Ili\u2019uun.name: Ili’uun
Ili\u2019uun.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Wetar
Ili\u2019uun.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ili’uun
Ili\u2019uun.dialects: Telemar, Karbubu, Ustutun, Klishatu, Ilmaumau, Eray, Nabar, Esulit. All also use the Ili’uun dialect. Lexical similarity: 93%–97% among dialects, 73% with Tugun
Ili\u2019uun.language_use: Jeh and Juru have no remaining speakers. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].
Ili\u2019uun.location: Maluku province: Erai, Esulit, Ilmaumau, Istutun, Karbubu, Klishatu, Nabar, and Telemar villages southwest; Lirang island; Wetar island southwest tip.

Yeretuar.name: Yeretuar
Yeretuar.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yeretuar
Yeretuar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yeretuar
Yeretuar.language_use: Two of three villages have shifted mostly to Wandamen [wad].
Yeretuar.location: Papua province: Nabire regency, lower Kwatisore bay; Papua Barat province: south Teluk Wondama regency, Wandamen peninsula.

Malay, Larantuka.alt_name: Bahasa Nagi, Ende Malay, Melayu Larantuka, Nagi
Malay, Larantuka.name: Malay, Larantuka
Malay, Larantuka.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Larantuka
Malay, Larantuka.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Flores Timur regency, Larantuka city area, and southwest Flores Strait towards Lewotobi town.

Itik.name: Itik
Itik.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Itik
Itik.other_comments: Survey data from 2005 indicates this language may no longer exist or speakers moved to another location. Christian, traditional religion.
Itik.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Itik.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, north coast on upper Biri river.

Ponosakan.name: Ponosakan
Ponosakan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Gorontalo-Mongondow, Mongondowic
Ponosakan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ponosakan
Ponosakan.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 75% with Mongondow
Ponosakan.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Belang town area.

Sause.name: Sause
Sause.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sause
Sause.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Orya [ury].
Sause.location: Papua Province, southwest of Sentani, northwest of Lereh, Ures, Mubararon, Sause-Bokoko, Witti-Yadow, Lidya, and Puaral villages.

Ulumanda\u2019.alt_name: Awo-Sumakuyu, Botteng-Tappalang, Kado, Oeloemanda, Tubbi, Ulumandak, Ulunda
Ulumanda\u2019.name: Ulumanda’
Ulumanda\u2019.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Pitu Ulunna Salu
Ulumanda\u2019.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ulumanda’
Ulumanda\u2019.dialects: Sondoang, Tappalang, Botteng. About 6 dialects. Lexical similarity: 75%–80% with dialect of Bambam
Ulumanda\u2019.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Majene, Mamuju, and Polewali-Mandar regencies, mostly interior.

Bugis.alt_name: Boegineesche, Boeginezen, Bugi, Buginese, De’, Rappang Buginese, To Ugi
Bugis.name: Bugis
Bugis.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bugis
Bugis.dialects: Bone (Dua Boccoe, Mare, Palakka), Pangkep (Pangkajene), Camba, Sidrap (Alitta, Pinrang Utara, Sidenrang), Pasangkayu (Ugi Riawa), Sinjai (Bulukumba, Enna, Palattae), Soppeng (Kessi), Wajo, Barru (Nepo, Pare-Pare, Soppeng Riaja, Tanete, Tompo), Sawitto (Pinrang), Luwu (Bua Ponrang, Luwu’, Malangke-Ussu, Wara). Bone and Soppeng dialects are central.
Bugis.language_use: Vigorous. Also use Balantak [blz], Indonesian [ind]. Also use Fordata [frd], in a few villages. Used as L2 by Kodeoha [vko], Lemolang [ley], Moronene [mqn], Rahambuu [raz], Selayar [sly], Wotu [wtw].
Bugis.location: Sulawesi Barat province: More, Pasangkayu on Mandar bay; Sulawesi Selatan province: widespread in peninsular interior (except south and east of Makassar city) east to Bone bay; Sulawesi Tengah province: Donggola, Oti, and Toaya, west; 3 Tolo bay enclaves east; Sulawesi Tenggara province: Kasiputih area, 3 interior enclaves near Sulawesi Tenggara, Lake Towuti, Bone bay east coast; possibly in Kalimantan, Maluku, Papua, and Sumatra provinces.
Bugis.typology: SVO; prepositions; noun head initial; verb affixes mark person; passives; causatives; 19 consonant and 6 vowel phonemes; non-tonal; stress on penultimate syllable.
Bugis.population: 5,500,000 in Indonesia, all users. 5,000,000 (2000 census), increasing. 500,000. Total users in all countries: 5,517,800 (as L1: 5,017,800; as L2: 500,000).

Sawai.name: Sawai
Sawai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, South Halmahera, Southeast
Sawai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sawai
Sawai.dialects: Weda, Sawai, Kobe, Faya-Mafa, Messa-Dote. Lexical similarity: 64% with North Nuaulu
Sawai.language_use: Some domains, local commerce. Youth are taught Indonesian [ind] first; then learn to understand Sawai. Positive attitudes. Also use Buli [bzq], Gane [gzn], Indonesian [ind], Maba [mqa], North Moluccan Malay [max], Patani [ptn], Ternate [tft], Tidore [tvo], Tobelo [tlb].
Sawai.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 5,000 can read it, 1,000 can write it. Bible portions: 1994–2005.
Sawai.location: Maluku Utara Province, Halmahera Tengah and Halmahera Selatan regencies, Gane Timur and Weda districts;13 villages. Halmahera island, southeast peninsula, Weda bay, both coasts: 13 villages.

Sikule.alt_name: Salang, Sichule, Sigulai, Sikhule, Simeulue Barat, Wali Banuah
Sikule.name: Sikule
Sikule.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Nias
Sikule.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sikule
Sikule.language_use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind] in Leukon dialect; vigorous in other areas. Some young people, all adults.

Lamboya.name: Lamboya
Lamboya.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Sumba-Hawu, Sumba
Lamboya.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lamboya
Lamboya.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Sumba island southwest coast.

Burmeso.alt_name: Boromeso, Borumesso, Burumeso, Manau, Monao, Monau, Taurap
Burmeso.name: Burmeso
Burmeso.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Burmeso
Burmeso.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: less than 5% with other languages.
Burmeso.language_use: Vigorous. Not spoken by outsiders. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Burmeso.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Mamberamo Tengah sub-district, 1 village on Middle Mamberamo river.

Awbono.name: Awbono
Awbono.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Awbono
Awbono.dialects: None known. Not related to these language families: Ok, Asmat, Awyu-Dumut, Momuna
Awbono.other_comments: Frequently at war with Kopkaka and Korowai.
Awbono.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency; Modera river area.

Luhu.name: Luhu
Luhu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Three Rivers, Amalumute, Northwest Seram
Luhu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Luhu
Luhu.dialects: Luhu, Batu Merah, Kelang. Lexical similarity: 72% with Luhu dialect, 71%–73% with Asilulu
Luhu.language_use: Vigorous. Batu Merah dialect spoken on Ambon Island has few remaining speakers. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].
Luhu.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Barat regency, Luhu village on northwest and south coast of Seram island, Boano and Manipa islands.

Karey.name: Karey
Karey.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Karey
Karey.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 70% with East Tarangan
Karey.location: Maluku province: Tarangan island southeast coast, Karey valley in Aru Islands.

Komering.name: Komering
Komering.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Komering
Komering.dialects: Upstream Komering, Downstream Komering, Komering, Kayu Agung Asli, Kayu Agung. Lexical similarity: 70% with the Kalianda dialect of Lampung Api
Komering.language_use: Vigorous. Home, village. All ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Musi [mui], in the market.
Komering.location: Sumatera Selatan province: Ogan Komering Ulu Selatan, Ogan Komering Ulu Timur, Ogan Komering Ulu, and Ogan Ilir regencies; along Komering river from Ranaumeer to near Palembang city.

Lasalimu.name: Lasalimu
Lasalimu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Buton, East Buton
Lasalimu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lasalimu
Lasalimu.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 68% with Kamaru
Lasalimu.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Buton regency, Lasalimu sub-district, Lasalima town, Lasalimu and Malaoge villages facing Lawelu bay on Buton island.

Laura.name: Laura
Laura.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Sumba-Hawu, Sumba
Laura.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Laura
Laura.dialects: Laura, Mbukambero (Bukambero). Not intelligible with Kodi
Laura.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Mamboru town west to Cape Karosso on northwest Sumba island.

Yawa.alt_name: Mantembu, Mora, Turu, Unat, Yapanani, Yava
Yawa.name: Yawa
Yawa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yawa
Yawa.dialects: Central Yawa (Mora), West Yawa, South Yawa, North Yawa, East Yawa.
Yawa.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–50%. Taught in the lower grades in some village schools. Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Yawa.location: Papua province: central Yapen island, 8 north coast villages, 2 interior villages, and 18 south coast villages.

Korupun-Sela.name: Korupun-Sela
Korupun-Sela.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Korupun-Sela
Korupun-Sela.dialects: Korupun (Duram), Dagi, Sisibna (Gobugdua), Deibula, Sela. Lexical similarity: 60% with Nipsan
Korupun-Sela.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency, Kurima sub-district in eastern highlands, on Erok river upper reaches.

Lepki.name: Lepki
Lepki.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lepki
Lepki.dialects: None known. Possible genetic similarities with Murkim
Lepki.language_use: Home, religious services, market. Some also use Ketengban [xte], at Luban.
Lepki.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency, Okbibab sub-district.
Lepki.typology: SOV; head and dependent marking; tonal.

Iha.name: Iha
Iha.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, West Bomberai, West Bomberai Proper
Iha.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Iha
Iha.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Baham
Iha.location: Papua Barat province: Fakfak regency, Fakfak, Kaimana, and Kokas sub-districts on west Bomberai peninsula.

Aputai.name: Aputai
Aputai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Wetar
Aputai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Aputai
Aputai.dialects: Ilputih, Lurang, Welemur. Welemur dialect has no remaining speakers. Lexical similarity: 93% among dialects, 79% with Perai
Aputai.language_use: Influence from Galolen [gal] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Also use Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Galolen [gal], especially Ilputih dialect speakers.
Aputai.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency; Wetar island, Banda Sea coast, Ilputih village; Wetar strait coast, Lurang village.

Mandobo Atas.alt_name: Dumut, Kambon, Kwem, Mandobbo, Nub, Wambon, “Kaeti” (pej.)
Mandobo Atas.name: Mandobo Atas
Mandobo Atas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mandobo Atas
Mandobo Atas.location: Papua province: between Tanahmerah and Mindiptanah towns, toward Fly river border in Papua New Guinea.

Dusun Deyah.name: Dusun Deyah
Dusun Deyah.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, East, Central-South, Central
Dusun Deyah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dusun Deyah
Dusun Deyah.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 53% with Lawangan
Dusun Deyah.location: Kalimantan Selatan province: Tabalong river northeast of Bongkang town; into Kalimantan Tengah province.

Konjo, Coastal.name: Konjo, Coastal
Konjo, Coastal.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Konjo, Coastal
Konjo, Coastal.dialects: Konjo Pesisir (Ara, Bira), Tana Toa (Black Konjo, Kadjang, Kajang, Tana Towa), Bantaeng (Bonthain). Tana Toa is north end of dialect subgroup. Lexical similarity: 76% with Makassar
Konjo, Coastal.other_comments: Tana Towa resist modern ways, contact with outsiders. Muslim, traditional religion.
Konjo, Coastal.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Bantaeng, Bulukumba, and Sinjai regencies; southeast peninsula on Salayer strait.

Manombai.name: Manombai
Manombai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Manombai
Manombai.dialects: None known. Not inherently intelligible with Dobel
Manombai.language_use: Vigorous. Also use Dobel [kvo]. Used as L2 by Dobel [kvo].
Manombai.location: Maluku province: Aru islands, Manombai strait to Wakua island, from Wokam village south, 21 villages; Kobror island, Benjina; Maikor island, Gardakau; Wokam island east coast, Kobamar village.

Naka\u2019ela.name: Naka’ela
Naka\u2019ela.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Three Rivers, Amalumute, Northwest Seram, Ulat Inai
Naka\u2019ela.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Naka’ela
Naka\u2019ela.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 71% with Lisabata-Nuniali
Naka\u2019ela.other_comments: Formerly lived in mountains then moved down to Kairatu.
Naka\u2019ela.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Barat regency, Kairatu village on southwest Seram island.

Asmat, Casuarina Coast.name: Asmat, Casuarina Coast
Asmat, Casuarina Coast.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Asmat, Casuarina Coast
Asmat, Casuarina Coast.location: Papua province: Mappi regency, Edera and Pantai Kasuari sub-districts on Casuarina Coast from Ewta river north to Kuti river south, and inland.
Asmat, Casuarina Coast.population: 9,000 (1991 SIL). 5,200 in Matia and 3,400 in Sapan.

Lorang.name: Lorang
Lorang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lorang
Lorang.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Koba
Lorang.location: Maluku Province: Aru islands group, Koba island on northwest coast.

Awyu, North.name: Awyu, North
Awyu, North.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Awyu, North
Awyu, North.location: Papua province: Merauke district; Digul river west side.

Mamboru.name: Mamboru
Mamboru.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Sumba-Hawu, Sumba
Mamboru.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mamboru
Mamboru.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: northwest Sumba island, coastal Memboro town.

Vitou.name: Vitou
Vitou.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Vitou
Vitou.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 63% with Betaf
Vitou.language_use: Mainly older adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Vitou.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Pantai Timur sub-district, Takar village inland.

Banggai.name: Banggai
Banggai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Saluan-Banggai, Eastern
Banggai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Banggai
Banggai.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Banggai Kepulauan regency, at least 157 villages; Banggai and Bowokan islands.

Makian, West.name: Makian, West
Makian, West.classification: West Papuan, North Halmahera, West Makian
Makian, West.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Makian, West
Makian, West.dialects: None known. Language isolate within north Halmahera. Formerly classified as Austronesian.
Makian, West.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera southwest coast, Kayoa, west Makian islands.
Makian, West.population: 12,000 (Voegelin and Voegelin 1977). 7,000 on Makian Island, 5,000 on Kayoa Islands.

Mawes.name: Mawes
Mawes.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mawes
Mawes.language_use: Home; with friends. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Mawes.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Bonggo sub-district, Mawes Dai, Mawes Mukti, and Mawes Wres villages on Buri river west bank inland.

Karon Dori.name: Karon Dori
Karon Dori.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Karon Dori
Karon Dori.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Mai Brat
Karon Dori.location: Papua Barat province: Asses, Pef, Siakwa, and Sunopi villages; central Bird’s Head Kamundan river headwaters area.

Kayagar.name: Kayagar
Kayagar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kayagar
Kayagar.dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Tamagario
Kayagar.language_use: Home, work. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Atohwaim [aqm].
Kayagar.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% somewhat literate in Indonesian [ind].
Kayagar.location: Papua province: Asmat and Mappi regencies, southwest coast from Arafura sea inland.

Malay.alt_name: Colloquial Malay, Informal Malay, Local Malay, Malayu
Malay.name: Malay
Malay.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay
Malay.dialects: Coastal Terengganu, Inland Terengganu, Kelantan, Pahang, Southeast Island, Jugra-Muar-Melaka-Johor, Sarawak (Sarawak Malay), Tamiang, Deli, Riau Mainland, Akit, Sakai, Riau islands, Coastal Jambi, Belitung, Northwestern Kalimantan, Upstream Western Kalimantan, Southwestern Coastal Kalimantan. Kedah Malay
Malay.other_comments: This entry refers to local or vernacular Malay varieties not well differentiated from each other, and other varieties for which further research is needed to clarify differentiation from mainstream dialects. Distinguished from court-Malay-derived Standard Indonesian
Malay.language_use: Also use English [eng], Standard Malay [zsm]. Used as L2 by Central Melanau [mel], Cheq Wong [cwg], Duano [dup], Jah Hut [jah], Jehai [jhi], Kensiu [kns], Kintaq [knq], Lanoh [lnh], Mah Meri [mhe], Malaccan Creole Portuguese [mcm], Minriq [mnq], Remun [lkj], Salako [knx], Semai [sea], Semaq Beri [szc], Semelai [sza], Southern Sama [ssb], Tamil [tam], Temiar [tea], Toraja [sda].
Malay.location: Peninsular Malaysia: widespread; Sarawak: Betong, Kuching, Samarahan, and Sri Aman districts.
Malay.population: 13,500,000 in Malaysia, all users. 10,500,000 (2004 census). 10 million in Peninsular Malaysia, 506,000 in Sarawak, and 30,000 in Labuan. 3,000,000. Total users in all countries: 19,122,700 (as L1: 16,122,700; as L2: 3,000,000).

Yetfa.status: 3 (Wider communication). Trade language in the area, extending to Papua New Guinea border.
Yetfa.name: Yetfa
Yetfa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yetfa
Yetfa.dialects: None known. Yetfa and Biksi are 2 ethnic groups, speaking the same language.
Yetfa.language_use: Home, market, religious services. Used as L2 by Murkim [rmh], Towei [ttn].
Yetfa.location: Papua province: Pegunungan Bintang regency, Okbibab sub-district.

Iban.status: 3 (Wider communication). Spoken from Sri Aman Division in the south west to Miri Division in the north east in the domains of market, church, business, and media.
Iban.name: Iban
Iban.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Iban
Iban.dialects: Batang Lupar, Bugau, Skrang, Dau, Lemanak, Ulu Ai, Undup.
Iban.language_use: Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bukitan [bkn], Kajaman [kag], Kiput [kyi], Narom [nrm], Remun [lkj].
Iban.language_development: Taught in primary schools in Sarawak. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1988–2011.
Iban.population: 1,452,000 in Malaysia, all users. 752,000 (2013 SIL). Including 2,300 in 2 villages in Sabah (2013 A. Maraining). 700,000 (2013 SIL). Total users in all countries: 1,484,300 (as L1: 784,300; as L2: 700,000).

Punan Tubu.name: Punan Tubu
Punan Tubu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Punan Tubu
Punan Tubu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Punan Tubu
Punan Tubu.other_comments: Not a Kenyah language (2003 A. Soriente). Penan is generic, nonagricultural peoples (Blust 1974). There are no Penan languages as a distinguishable subgroup.
Punan Tubu.location: Kalimantan Timur province: Malinau, Mentarang, and Sembakung river areas.

Laiyolo.name: Laiyolo
Laiyolo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Laiyolo
Laiyolo.dialects: Barang-Barang (Loa, Loa’, Lowa), Laiyolo (Lajolo, Layolo). Lexical similarity: 86% between Laiyolo and Barang-Barang dialect, 76% with Kalao
Laiyolo.language_use: Vigorous in Barang-Barang dialect. Mainly adults in Laiyolo; all ages in Barang-Barang. Many also use Selayar [sly]. A few also use Indonesian [ind].
Laiyolo.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Kepulauan Selayar regency, Barang-Barang, Laiyolo, Lowa, and other villages on Selayar island south tip.

Namla.name: Namla
Namla.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Namla
Namla.dialects: None known. Possible genetic relationship to Tofanma
Namla.language_use: All also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Tofanma [tlg].
Namla.location: Papua province: Keerom regency, Senggi sub-district, Namla village.

Badui.name: Badui
Badui.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Badui
Badui.dialects: Sometimes considered a dialect of Sunda
Badui.other_comments: A separate socio-religious group from Sunda
Badui.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes.
Badui.location: Banten province: Rangkasbitung regency, Pandeglang town, on Ujung river; Jawa Barat province: Sukabumi city area, 1 village, and Cikajang city area.

Murkim.name: Murkim
Murkim.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Murkim
Murkim.dialects: None known. Possible genetic relationship to Lepki
Murkim.language_use: Home, community. All ages. Also use Kimki [sbt], Yetfa [yet].
Murkim.location: Papua province: Pegunungan Bintang regency, Batom sub-district, Milki and Mot villages.

Bidayuh, Biatah.alt_name: Biatah, Bikuab, Kuap, Quop, Sentah, Siburan
Bidayuh, Biatah.name: Bidayuh, Biatah
Bidayuh, Biatah.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Land Dayak, Bidayuh, Core, Central
Bidayuh, Biatah.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bidayuh, Biatah
Bidayuh, Biatah.dialects: Siburan, Stang (Bisitaang, Sitaang), Tibia. Not intelligible with Bukar-Sadong Bidayuh
Bidayuh, Biatah.other_comments: ’Bidayuh’ is a cover term for all Sarawak Land Dayak groups, plus Salako
Bidayuh, Biatah.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Radio. Bible: 2014.
Bidayuh, Biatah.location: Sarawak: Kuching division, Kuching district, 10 villages.
Bidayuh, Biatah.population: 63,900 (2000 census). Total users in all countries: 72,380.

Yei.name: Yei
Yei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yei
Yei.dialects: Upper Yei, Lower Yei. Dialects mutually inherently intelligible only with difficulty.
Yei.other_comments: Different cultural group from Marind. Christian, traditional religion.
Yei.language_use: Home. Also use Marind [mrz], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Yei.location: Papua province: Merauke regency, 6 villages in south coast area, along Maro river.

Moronene.name: Moronene
Moronene.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Eastern, Southwest
Moronene.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Moronene
Moronene.dialects: Wita Ea (Poleang, Rumbia), Tokotu’a (Kabaena). Lexical similarity: Wita Ea dialect 80% with Tokotu’a dialect; 68% with Menui dialect of Wawonii
Moronene.language_use: Vigorous in many villages. Occasional oral use in church, letter writing. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Bugis [bug], in Poleang. Also use Indonesian [ind], in some villages, especially some parents to their children.
Moronene.language_development: Taught as an oral and written subject in both elementary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio. NT: 2013.
Moronene.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Bombana regency, Bombana district, Wita Ea village; Rumbia mountains on southeast mainland; Kabaena island, Tokotu’a village; mainland opposite Kabaena. Rumbia, Poleang, and Poleang Timur sub-districts (Wita Ea dialect).
Moronene.population: 37,000 (2000 D. Andersen), increasing. Wita Ea 23,000, Tokotu’a 14,000. Includes about 3,500 living in cities. Second or third generations in cities no longer speak Moronene. 1,850 monolinguals.

Sentani.name: Sentani
Sentani.classification: East Bird’s Head-Sentani, Sentani, Sentani Proper
Sentani.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sentani
Sentani.dialects: East Sentani, West Sentani, Central Sentani. Lexical similarity: 30% with Tabla
Sentani.language_use: Vigorous use in most families. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Sentani.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 16%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. About 5,000. Schools are beginning to use Sentani grades 1 to 6. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Sentani.location: Papua province: Lake Sentani area, about 30 scattered villages; scattered in other parts of Indonesia.

Bonerate.name: Bonerate
Bonerate.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Tukangbesi-Bonerate
Bonerate.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bonerate
Bonerate.dialects: Bonerate, Karompa. Lexical similarity: 79%–81% with Tukang Besi South
Bonerate.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Bonerate, Madu, Kalaotoa, Karompa, and Selayer islands.

Waioli.name: Waioli
Waioli.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Waioli
Waioli.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 81% with Gamkonora
Waioli.location: Maluku Utara province: northwest Halmahera island coast from Sasu town inland to highland interior.

Sawi.name: Sawi
Sawi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sawi
Sawi.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Atohwaim [aqm].
Sawi.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% semiliterate. NT: 1973–1994.
Sawi.location: Papua Province, Asmat Regency, Pantai Kasuari and Fayit subdistricts, near south coastal lowland, between Kronkel and Ayip rivers and upper Fayit river area, Kamur, Esebor, Wiagas, Minahai, and Comoro villages.

Bukat.name: Bukat
Bukat.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Muller-Schwaner ‘Punan’
Bukat.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bukat
Bukat.location: Kalimantan Barat province: northeast near Sarawak border, Kapuas river, 3 areas.

Bada.name: Bada
Bada.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Kaili-Pamona, Southern, Badaic
Bada.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bada
Bada.dialects: Bada, Ako. Lexical similarity: 85% with Bada and Behoa
Bada.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Bada.location: Sulawesi Tengah and border area Sulawesi Selatan provinces: Luwu Utara and Poso regencies, Lore Selatan, Pamona Selatan, Parigi, and Poso Pesisir sub-districts; at least 24 villages. Northern Mamuju regency, Pasangkayu sub-district; some in Ampibabo sub-district, Lemusa village (Ako dialect).

Javanese.status: 4 (Educational). De facto language of provincial identity in central and eastern Java.
Javanese.name: Javanese
Javanese.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Javanese
Javanese.dialects: Cirebon (Cheribon, Tjirebon), Tegal, Indramayu, Surakarta (Sawlaw, Solo), Tembung, Pasisir, Surabaya, Malang-Pasuruan, Banten, Manuk, Banyumas. High Javanese (Jawa Halus) is the language of religion, but users diminishing and mostly limited to Central Javanese speakers. Javanese varieties in Suriname and in New Caledonia now only partially intelligible with difficulty. Javanese in New Caledonia reportedly cannot use High Javanese (Koentjaraningrat 1971). Several dialects in Sabah.
Javanese.language_use: Also use Musi [mui], especially in South Sumatra. Used as L2 by Madura [mad], Tengger [tes].
Javanese.location: Widespread. Mainly Jawa Tengah, Jawa Timur, Lampung, and Yogyakarta provinces; Sumatra island: scattered; resettlements in Kalimantan, Maluku, Papua, and Sulawesi.
Javanese.population: 84,300,000 (2000 census). 25,000 in south Sulawesi, and 69,000,000 on Java, 500,000 of them being in Banten region and 2,500,000 in Cirebon region of Java. Ethnic population: 95,200,000 (2011 census). Total users in all countries: 84,368,500.

Batak Toba.name: Batak Toba
Batak Toba.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Batak, Southern
Batak Toba.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batak Toba
Batak Toba.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Angkola Batak
Batak Toba.language_use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind] in urban and migrant areas. Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Religion, Education. Some young people, all adults.
Batak Toba.location: Sumatera Utara province: Asahan, Humbang Hasundutan, Labuhan Batu Utara, Samosir, Simalungan, south Tapanuli Tengah, Tapanuli Utara, and Toba Samosir regencies; Samosir island; east, south, and west of Lake Toba.

Burate.name: Burate
Burate.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Burate
Burate.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 69% with Demisa
Burate.location: Papua province: Yapen Waropen regency, Waropen Bawah sub-district, 1 village near Wapoga river mouth.

Masela, West.name: Masela, West
Masela, West.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Babar, South, Masela-South Babar
Masela, West.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Masela, West
Masela, West.language_use: Vigorous. Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], in all domains, except home and certain cultural practices. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.
Masela, West.location: Maluku province: 5 villages on Masela island west tip.

Hukumina.name: Hukumina
Hukumina.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Hukumina
Hukumina.location: Maluku province: Hukumina, Palumata, and Tomahu districts on northwest Buru island.

Kofei.name: Kofei
Kofei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kofei
Kofei.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 67% with Barapasi
Kofei.location: Papua province: Mamberamo Raya and Waropen regencies; east side of Cendrawasih bay.

Moskona.name: Moskona
Moskona.classification: East Bird’s Head-Sentani, East Bird’s Head, Meax
Moskona.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Moskona
Moskona.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 85% with Meyah
Moskona.location: Papua Barat province: southeast Bird’s Head, west Bituni Bay; Sebjor river basin.

Ujir.name: Ujir
Ujir.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ujir
Ujir.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 75% with Kola
Ujir.language_use: Use declining in Ujir because Malay [abs] used increasingly by outsiders. Use reportedly less in Samang than in Ujir.
Ujir.location: Maluku province: Kepulauan-Aru regency; northwest Aru islands on Udjir and Wokam islands.

Lampung Nyo.name: Lampung Nyo
Lampung Nyo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lampung Nyo
Lampung Nyo.dialects: Abung, Tulangbawang, Sukadana, Melinting. Many differences in vocabulary and phonology with Lampung Api
Lampung Nyo.language_use: Home. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially in education, religion, and civil domains.
Lampung Nyo.language_development: Taught in primary schools, as an auxiliary medium. Literature.
Lampung Nyo.location: Lampung province: 3 enclaves east between Kanan and Seputih rivers.

Kangean.name: Kangean
Kangean.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kangean
Kangean.dialects: None known. Barely intelligible with East Madura
Kangean.location: Java island, Jawa Timur province: sea coast; Kangean islands.

Koba.name: Koba
Koba.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Koba
Koba.dialects: Southeast Koba. Low comprehension of Dobel
Koba.location: Maluku province: southeast, at least 3 villages; Aru island group, Baun and Fukarel islands in mouth of Barakai strait.

Perai.name: Perai
Perai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Wetar
Perai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Perai
Perai.dialects: Moning, Uhak. Lexical similarity: 93% among dialects, 79% with Aputai
Perai.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency, Moning and Uhak villages on Wetar island northeast coast.

Yeresiam.name: Yeresiam
Yeresiam.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Iresim
Yeresiam.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yeresiam
Yeresiam.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifting to Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Yeresiam.location: Papua province: Nabire regency, south Cenderawasih bay, Yamur lake area; Papua Barat province: Kaimana regency.

Kwerba.alt_name: Air Mati, Airmati, Armati, Koassa, Mataweja, Naibedj, Segar Tor, Serikenam, Tekutameso
Kwerba.name: Kwerba
Kwerba.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kwerba
Kwerba.dialects: Serikenam, Sasawa, Nogukwabai. Lexical similarity: 64% with Bagusa
Kwerba.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Bible portions: 1986–2001.
Kwerba.location: Papua province: Apiaweti, Aurime, Munukania, Tatsewalem, and Wamariri villages in Apauwer river headwaters.

Morop.name: Morop
Morop.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Morop
Morop.other_comments: Dintere most widespread dialect. Relationship between Nemah and Dintere is unclear and may constitute more than one language. Christian, traditional religion.
Morop.location: Papua province: Iwur river valley border area, Ok Iwur east to Ok Denom. Dewok (Dinamne dialect); Aurarin hamlet (Upper Dintere dialect).

Massep.name: Massep
Massep.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Massep
Massep.language_use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Isirawa [srl], Samarokena [tmj] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home, religious services.
Massep.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, north coast; also west of Sarmi near Apauwer river.

Kadai.name: Kadai
Kadai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, Sula, Taliabo
Kadai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kadai
Kadai.dialects: None known. May be intelligible with Taliabu
Kadai.other_comments: The government wants to resettle them along the coast. Traditional religion.
Kadai.location: Maluku Utara province: Kepulauan Sula regency in Sula Islands, Molucca sea coast, Tjapaplulu strait area; Taliabu island, 2 east coast groups; west Mangole island coast east from Dofa; 2 small offshore islands.

Batui.name: Batui
Batui.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Saluan-Banggai, Western, Saluanic
Batui.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batui
Batui.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 74% with Saluan
Batui.language_use: Home, cultural events. Most parents do not pass language on to their children (2006). Positive attitudes.
Batui.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Banggai regency, Batui sub-district, Balantang, Batui, Sisipan, and Tolando villages; eastern peninsula.

Tii.alt_name: Rote, Rote Barat, Roti, Rotinese, Thie, Ti, Western Rote
Tii.name: Tii
Tii.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Nuclear Timor, Rote
Tii.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tii
Tii.dialects: Minor variation, third singular verb prefix, na-fa’da, varies with, i-fa’da.
Tii.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Kupang Malay [mkn].
Tii.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: southwest Rote island.

Levuka.name: Levuka
Levuka.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Levuka
Levuka.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: west central Lembata island.

Asmat, Central.name: Asmat, Central
Asmat, Central.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Asmat, Central
Asmat, Central.dialects: Simai (Simay), Misman, Ajam (Ayam). Reportedly similar to Sempan
Asmat, Central.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 5% in Indonesian [ind]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1985.
Asmat, Central.location: Papua province: Asmat regency; Sawa-Erma, Agats, Atsy, and Pantai Kasuari sub-districts, south coast from Owap river northwest to Farec river southwest, inland; Mappi regency, Edera and Nambai sub-districts in Digul river delta area.

Saweru.name: Saweru
Saweru.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Saweru
Saweru.location: Papua Province, Serui Waropen regency, Yapen Selatan subdistrict, central Yapen island, an island south of Yapen island near Serui.

Yali, Pass Valley.alt_name: Abendago, North Ngalik, Pass Valley, Western Yali, Yaly
Yali, Pass Valley.name: Yali, Pass Valley
Yali, Pass Valley.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yali, Pass Valley
Yali, Pass Valley.location: Papua province: central highlands, Jayawijaya, Kurima, and Kurulu regencies.

Muna.name: Muna
Muna.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Munan, Munic, Western
Muna.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Muna
Muna.dialects: Standard Muna (Northern Muna), Tiworo (Eastern Muna), Gu, Lakudo, Mawasangka, Kadatua, Siompu, Katobengke, Burukene, Laompo, Kapontori. Subvarieties of standard Muna are: Tungkuno, Kabawo, Lawa, Katobu, Tobea Besar; of Gulamas are: Gu, Mawasangka, Lakudo, Wale-Ale, Lawama, Kadatua, Lowu-Lowu, Kalia-Lia, Katobengke, Topa, Salaa, Lawela, Laompo, and Burukene. Lexical similarity: 71% with Pancana
Muna.language_use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Taloki [tlk].
Muna.language_development: Taught in primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Muna.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Buton regency, Kadatuang and Siumpu islands; some in Ambon city; Buton Utara regency on northwest Buton island along Buntung strait, from Puntau north past Lebo; Muna regency, Muna and Tiworo islands.

Marau.name: Marau
Marau.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, Central-Western
Marau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Marau
Marau.dialects: Warabori (Natabui, Warembori). Probably the same language as Munggui
Marau.location: Papua province: 5 villages on east Yapen island, Cenderawasih bay.

Rampi.name: Rampi
Rampi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Rampi
Rampi.dialects: Rampi (Lambu), Rato. Leboni is prestige dialect.
Rampi.language_use: Vigorous in some villages. Used as L2 by Uma [ppk].
Rampi.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Luwu Utara regency, Rampi district, 6 mountain villages; Limbong, Mangkutana, Sabbang, and Wotu districts scattered; Sulawesi Tengah province: border area southwest of Lake Poso.
Rampi.population: 10,000 (2006). 2,300 in South Sulawesi, 5,700 in Central Sulawesi.

Kayan, Busang.name: Kayan, Busang
Kayan, Busang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Kayan Proper
Kayan, Busang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kayan, Busang
Kayan, Busang.location: Kalimantan Tengah province; Kalimantan Timur province: Muller Mountains, Belayan, upper Mahakam, and Oga river areas.

Lampung Api.name: Lampung Api
Lampung Api.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lampung Api
Lampung Api.dialects: Krui (Kroe, Kru’i, Njo, Western Lampung), Southern Pesisir, Pubian, Ranau, Sungkai, Daya.
Lampung Api.other_comments: Teachers must use L1, especially in lower grades. Muslim.
Lampung Api.language_use: Outside of the city, home and village everyday. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Lampung Api.location: Bengkulu province: Kaur regency; Lampung province: Lampung Barat and Tanggamus regencies in Semangko bay area; Way Kanan, north Lampung, and Pringsewu regencies on Lampung bay east coast; also Sebuku, Sebesi, Tabuan, and Legundi islands; Sumatera Selatan province: Ogan Komering Ulu, Ogan Komering Ulu Selatan, and Ogan Komering Ulu Timur regencies, near Kanan river headwaters.

Malay, Banda.name: Malay, Banda
Malay, Banda.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Banda
Malay, Banda.dialects: May better be considered a dialect of Moluccan (Ambonese) Malay

Woria.name: Woria
Woria.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Woria
Woria.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 64% with Barapasi
Woria.other_comments: Botawa is a Demisa and Waropen
Woria.location: Papua province: Waropen regency, Botawa village; Sanoringga river mouth to interior, and northeast.

Gayo.name: Gayo
Gayo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Gayo
Gayo.dialects: Deret, Serbejadi-Lukup, Lut, Lues. Not closely related to other languages. Some Gayo people consider Alas
Gayo.language_use: Home, neighborhood, clinic, market, ceremonies, village meetings. All ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Indonesian [ind].
Gayo.language_development: Taught in primary schools 2 hours a week called local instruction. Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Gayo.location: Aceh province: Central Aceh, East Aceh, Gayo Lues, and Southeast Aceh regencies; Sumatra highland region near Mount Sembuang.

Skou.alt_name: Sekol, Sekou, Sko, Skouw, Skow, Sukou, Te Mawo, Tumawo
Skou.name: Skou
Skou.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Skou
Skou.language_use: All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy], Vanimo [vam], Wutung [wut].
Skou.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Indonesian [ind]. Literacy motivation high, program in progress. Dictionary. Grammar.
Skou.location: Papua province: Sko-Mabu, Sko-Sai, and Sko-Yambe villages, north coast border area at Tami river mouth.

Mori Atas.alt_name: Aikoa, Berg-Tomori, Boven-Mori, Upper Mori, West Mori
Mori Atas.name: Mori Atas
Mori Atas.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Western, Interior
Mori Atas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mori Atas
Mori Atas.dialects: Impo, Molio’a, Molongkuni, Ulu Uwoi, Tambee (Ajo, South Mori, Zuid-Mori). Lexical similarity: 73%–86% with Mori Bawah
Mori Atas.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Lembo, Mori Atas, and Petasia sub-districts, 25 villages on southeast peninsula neck; Sulawesi Selatan province: Nuha sub-district.

Kemtuik.name: Kemtuik
Kemtuik.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kemtuik
Kemtuik.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 80% with Gresi
Kemtuik.language_use: All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Mlap [kja].
Kemtuik.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2008.
Kemtuik.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Aib, Aimbe, Braso, Mamda, Mamdayawang, Meikari, Merem, Sabeyap, Sabeyap Kecil, Sabron Yaru, Sabransamon, Sekorup, and Yanim villages; Lake Sentani southwest area.

Bagusa.name: Bagusa
Bagusa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bagusa
Bagusa.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 64% with Kwerba
Bagusa.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Mamberamo Tengah sub-district.

Onin.name: Onin
Onin.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, North Bomberai
Onin.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Onin
Onin.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Iha [ihp] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Onin.location: Papua Barat province: Fakfak regency on north Bomberai peninsula in Berau bay south coast west to Wetin point, then southwest to Wirtopin bay; south coast facing Panjang island.

Nisa.name: Nisa
Nisa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nisa
Nisa.location: Papua province: east Geelvink bay inland, Danau Nisa area.

Asmat, North.name: Asmat, North
Asmat, North.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Asmat, North
Asmat, North.language_use: Most domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Asmat, North.location: Papua province: Merauke regency, Sawa-Erma sub-district. Near Pater Le Cocq river headwaters west to Unir river east to the foothills.

Arguni.name: Arguni
Arguni.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, North Bomberai
Arguni.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Arguni
Arguni.location: Papua Barat province: Fak-Fak district; Arguni island in Maccluer gulf off northwest coast, Bomberai peninsula.

Duvle.name: Duvle
Duvle.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Duvle
Duvle.dialects: Eastern Duvle, Western Duvle. Few dialect differences.
Duvle.language_use: Vigorous. Also use Wano [wno]. Used as L2 by Iau [tmu].
Duvle.location: Papua province: south of Van Daalen river; Dagai river (Eastern Duvle), Fedide and Wedi rivers (Western Duvle).

Mamasa.name: Mamasa
Mamasa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Toraja-Sa’dan
Mamasa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mamasa
Mamasa.dialects: Northern Mamasa, Central Mamasa, Pattae’ (Binuang, Binuang-Paki-Batetanga-Anteapi, Patta’ Binuang, Southern Mamasa, Tae’). Lexical similarity: 78% with Toraja-Sa’dan
Mamasa.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Mamasa regency, along Mamasa river; Sulawesi Selatan province: north Pare-Pare area.

Karas.name: Karas
Karas.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, West Bomberai, Karas
Karas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Karas
Karas.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Iha [ihp] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Karas.location: Papua Barat province: Antalisa and Mas villages on Karas island.

Aralle-Tabulahan.name: Aralle-Tabulahan
Aralle-Tabulahan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Pitu Ulunna Salu
Aralle-Tabulahan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Aralle-Tabulahan
Aralle-Tabulahan.dialects: Aralle, Tabulahan, Mambi. Lexical similarity: 84%–89% with other dialects listed, 75%–80% with Bambam
Aralle-Tabulahan.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Mamasa regency, Mambi sub-district, Aralle and Tabulalang towns, 2 separate areas.

Masiwang.name: Masiwang
Masiwang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Masiwang
Masiwang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Masiwang
Masiwang.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 44% with Bobot
Masiwang.language_use: Also use Geser-Gorom [ges]. Used as L2 by Salas [sgu].
Masiwang.location: Maluku province: Bula district along Seram island northeast coast.

Col.name: Col
Col.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Col
Col.dialects: Lembak Delapan, Sindang Kelingi, Beliti, Lubuk Linggau. A member of macrolanguage Malay
Col.other_comments: The Lembak Delapan dialect of Col in Bengkulu is not to be confused with the Lembak subdialect of the Belide dialect of Musi
Col.language_use: Vigorous. Home, village. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], in civic and educational domains. Also use Musi [mui], specifically the urban Palembang dialect, as a trade language with neighboring groups.
Col.language_development: Literacy valued in Indonesian. Taught in primary schools. Grammar.
Col.location: Bengkulu and Sumatera Selatan provinces: Lubuklinggau and Muaraklingi areas south, east, and north; small group east of Bengkulu city.

Pendau.name: Pendau
Pendau.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Southern
Pendau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pendau
Pendau.language_use: Pendau is the everyday language in their settlements. They use Indonesian [ind] with outside officials. Children’s education is in Indonesian (2007).
Pendau.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Balaesang sub-district, Sibayu, Walandano, and other villages; scattered north to Dampal Utara district.

Indonesian, Peranakan.name: Indonesian, Peranakan
Indonesian, Peranakan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Indonesian, Peranakan
Indonesian, Peranakan.location: Jawa Barat, Jawa Tengah, and Jawa Timur provinces scattered on north coast; Yogyakarta province.

Sauri.name: Sauri
Sauri.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sauri
Sauri.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 71% with Barapasi
Sauri.language_use: Under some pressure from Waropen [wrp] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Sauri.location: Papua province: Waropen regency, Sauri-Sirami village on east Cenderawasih bay.

Malay, Berau.name: Malay, Berau
Malay, Berau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Berau
Malay, Berau.other_comments: Shares phonological innovations with Kutai Malay
Malay, Berau.location: Kalimantan Timur province: Cape Pandan, Tanjungreder, and Muaramalinau towns on lower Segah river; Celebes Sea coast and south past Sepinang town to Cape Batube area.

Ambai.name: Ambai
Ambai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, Central-Western
Ambai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ambai
Ambai.dialects: Randawaya, Ambai (Wadapi-Laut), Manawi. Lexical similarity: 77% with Serui-Laut
Ambai.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 2010.
Ambai.location: Papua province: Yapen Waropen regency, Yapen Selatan and Yapen Timur sub-districts, 10 villages on Ambai island, Cenderawasih bay, and Yapen island south coast.
Ambai.typology: Serial verbs; complex directional demonstrative system.

Dakka.name: Dakka
Dakka.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Pitu Ulunna Salu
Dakka.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dakka
Dakka.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 72%–77% with Pannei
Dakka.language_use: Dakka is spoken in a mixed language area including Mandar [mdr], Bugis [bug] and other immigrants.
Dakka.location: Sulawesi Barat province: Polewali-Mandar regency, Wonomulyo sub-district.

Oirata.name: Oirata
Oirata.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Oirata
Oirata.dialects: None known. Not related to other languages on Oirata or to central Maluku languages. Not closely related to languages in East Timor.
Oirata.language_use: A few also use Kisar [kje], on Kisar island.
Oirata.location: Maluku province: southeast Maluku Barat Daya regency; Kisar island, Oirata village; some in Ambon city.

Tehit.name: Tehit
Tehit.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tehit
Tehit.dialects: Tehit Jit, Mbol Fle, Saifi, Imyan, Sfa Riere, Fkar, Sawiat Salmeit. Lexical similarity: 60% with Kalabra.
Tehit.language_use: Vigorous. Parents in villages in the interior pass Tehit on to children. In villages bordering towns, Indonesian [ind] used with children. Users of neighboring languages learn Tehit. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Dutch [nld], English [eng], Mai Brat [ayz]. Also use Indonesian [ind], particularly in schools and as LWC.
Tehit.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught in primary schools. Bible portions: 1998.
Tehit.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong regency, most of Teminabuan sub-district, half of Sawiat sub-district, about 31 villages in southwest Bird’s Head.

Emplawas.name: Emplawas
Emplawas.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Babar, South, Southwest Babar
Emplawas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Emplawas
Emplawas.language_use: Almost complete shift to the regional Malay variety, which is probably a dialect of Ambonese Malay [abs] or Indonesian [ind], which is used in all domains. Speakers also use Indonesian primarily in government and Christian religious domains. Only the elders.
Emplawas.location: Maluku province: Maluku Barat Daya regency, Emplawas village, south Babar island.

So\u2019a.name: So’a
So\u2019a.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about So’a
So\u2019a.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Ngad’a
So\u2019a.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Flores island, central Kabupaten Ngada.

Sula.name: Sula
Sula.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, Sula
Sula.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sula
Sula.dialects: Fagudu, Falahu, Facei (Facé). Reportedly similar to Mangole
Sula.location: Maluku Utara province: Sula islands; Sula Besi (Sanana) island, widespread; Mangole island scattered on east, west and north coasts; Buru island northeast coast.

Madura.name: Madura
Madura.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Madura
Madura.dialects: Bawean (Babean, Bhebien, Boyanese), Bangkalan (Bangkalon), Pamekesan (Pamekasan), Sampang, Sapudi, Sumenep. Dialect continuum. Reports differ about inherent intelligibility among dialects: some Sumenep and Sampang report they cannot understand Pamekasan or Sumenep. Difficult intelligibility with Kangean
Madura.other_comments: Mainly rural. Bawean consider their language separate from Madurese. East Madurese, especially Sumenep, is considered high, or standard Madurese. Sumenep is isolated culturally and geographically. Bangkalon, spoken in Surabaya, is important economically because that city is highly urbanized and is most affected by Bahasa Indonesia. Muslim.
Madura.language_use: Vigorous on Madura Island and East Java. All domains. All ages. Also use Indonesian [ind], Javanese [jav].
Madura.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literacy higher among Bangkalon. Taught in primary schools (religious education). Taught in secondary schools (religious education). Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1994.
Madura.location: Jawa Timur province: Java island coast south and west of Surabaja city, Bawean, Kangean, and Sapudi islands; Kalimantan Selatan province: Java Sea area.
Madura.population: 6,770,000 (2000 census), decreasing. 86,000 Bawean. 2000 census reports large population decrease. Due to intermarriage, language attitudes, and other socioeconomic issues, the Madurese population is likely underreported. Ethnic population: 7,180,000 (2011 census). Total users in all countries: 6,770,900.

Segai.name: Segai
Segai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Modang
Segai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Segai
Segai.dialects: Kelai, Segah. Called Segayi by the Berau, Ga’ay by the Kenyah and Kayan.
Segai.location: Kalimantan Timur Province, Berau regency. Kelai river area around Longlaai town.

Nggem.name: Nggem
Nggem.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Dani, Dani Proper
Nggem.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nggem
Nggem.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 67% with Yali
Nggem.location: Papua province: middle Hablifoeri river north of Wamena.

Kwinsu.name: Kwinsu
Kwinsu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kwinsu
Kwinsu.language_use: Children seldom speak it. Only adults are fluent. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Kwinsu.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Pantai Timur sub-district, Ansudu village.

Termanu.alt_name: Central Rote, Pa’da, Rote, Rote Tengah, Roti, Rotinese
Termanu.name: Termanu
Termanu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Nuclear Timor, Rote
Termanu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Termanu
Termanu.dialects: Pa’da (Termanu), Pa’da Kona (Keka-Talae, Southern Termanu), Korbafo (Korbaffo), Bokai. Reportedly seems more similar to Lole
Termanu.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Some also use Dutch [nld], especially educated older people. Also use Indonesian [ind], Kupang Malay [mkn].
Termanu.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Bokai, Keka, Korbafo, Talae, and Termanu areas on central Rote island.

Ambelau.name: Ambelau
Ambelau.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, Ambelau
Ambelau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ambelau
Ambelau.dialects: None known. Not intelligible with Buru
Ambelau.other_comments: Schools through junior high on the island. Wild pigs and rocky terrain on Ambelau make cultivation impossible; that is done in Wae Tawa village on Buru Island. Muslim.
Ambelau.location: Maluku province: central Ambelau island; Buru island coast, Wae Tawa village; 8 villages.

Kamberau.name: Kamberau
Kamberau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kamberau
Kamberau.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 60% with Buruwai
Kamberau.location: Papua Barat province: Kaimana regency, Bahomia, Coa, Inari, Koi, Tanggaromi, Ubia-Seramuku, Waho, Wamesa, and Wamoma villages; southeast Bomberai peninsula, Kamerau bay area.

Wemale.name: Wemale
Wemale.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Three Rivers, Wemale
Wemale.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Wemale
Wemale.dialects: West Wemale, West-Central Wemale, East Wemale, South Wemale. Lexical similarity: 84% with east and west dialects, 70% with South Wemale dialect.
Wemale.language_use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, traditional ceremonies. All ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Ambonese Malay [abs].
Wemale.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Indonesian [ind].
Wemale.location: Maluku province: at least 14 villages on Seram island north coast, from Taniwel to Walakone towns; also southwest Seram.

Suwawa.alt_name: Bonda, Bone, Bunda, Bune, Suvava, Toewawa
Suwawa.name: Suwawa
Suwawa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Gorontalo-Mongondow, Gorontalic
Suwawa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Suwawa
Suwawa.location: Gorontalo province: Bone Bolango regency, Bunda river valley; Sulawesi Utara province: Bolaang Mongondow, Bolaang Mongondow Selantan, and Bolaang Mongondow Utara regencies in Pinogu area inland.

Tobelo.name: Tobelo
Tobelo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tobelo
Tobelo.other_comments: Taught in middle school in Tobelo town. Traditional religion, Christian.
Tobelo.language_use: Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], North Moluccan Malay [max]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].
Tobelo.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2002.
Tobelo.location: Maluku Utara province: Kao, Jailolo, and Tubelo districts on north Halmahera island; Maba and Wasile districts on central Halmahera; Morotai island central east coast; Ambon, Bacan, Gane, Obi, Patani, Raja Ampat, and Weda islands; Papua province: Sorong area.

Hatam.alt_name: Adihup, Atam, Borai, Hattam, Mansim, Miriei, Moi, Tinam, Uran
Hatam.name: Hatam
Hatam.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Hatam

Behoa.name: Behoa
Behoa.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Kaili-Pamona, Southern, Badaic
Behoa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Behoa
Behoa.dialects: None known. Geographically, politically, culturally, and lexically distinct from Bada
Behoa.language_use: 70% are speakers. Behoa is passed on to more than 60% of the children. Younger generation now prefers Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Most domains. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind].
Behoa.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Poso regency, Lore Utara sub-district, 8 villages; Behoa and Napu valleys.

Korowai.name: Korowai
Korowai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Korowai
Korowai.dialects: North Korowai, South Korowai. Dialects have high mutual intelligibility. Lexical similarity: 90% with dialects.
Korowai.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Also use Indonesian [ind], particularly younger village speakers.
Korowai.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 1% (2007 P. de Vries). Literacy rate in L2: Less than 1% in Indonesian [ind] (2007 P. de Vries). Grammar.
Korowai.location: Papua province: southeast inland area between upper Sirac and Digul rivers.

Kopkaka.name: Kopkaka
Kopkaka.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kopkaka
Kopkaka.dialects: Marub, Tokuni. Reportedly similar to Kwer
Kopkaka.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency, Kurima sub-district, Burungmakok and Siradala villages in lowlands; headwaters area, and Sirac river tributaries.

Tombelala.name: Tombelala
Tombelala.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Kaili-Pamona, Northern, Pamona
Tombelala.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tombelala
Tombelala.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 66%–76% with Pamona
Tombelala.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Morowali regency, Bungku Tengah sub-district, 4 villages on Tolo bay west coast.

Abun.name: Abun
Abun.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Abun
Abun.dialects: Abun Tat (Karon Pantai), Abun Ji (Madik), Abun Je.
Abun.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Abun.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong regency, Ayamaru, Moraid, and Sausapor sub-districts, about 20 villages; north coast, interior of central Bird’s Head.

Lauje.name: Lauje
Lauje.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Northern
Lauje.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lauje
Lauje.dialects: Ampibabo (Ampibabo-Lauje). Ampibabo dialect may be a separate language.
Lauje.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Donggala and Parigi Moutong regencies, Ampibabo, Dampelas Sojol, Dondo, Tinombo, and Tomini sub-districts in Sidoan river area.

Haji.name: Haji
Haji.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Haji
Haji.dialects: None known. Genetically Malay with approximately one-third Lampung vocabulary. A member of macrolanguage Malay
Haji.language_use: Vigorous. Domestic and village life. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], in education, religious, and civic domains.
Haji.location: Sumatera Selatan province: Ogan Komering Ulu Selatan regency, 2 areas on Sumatra.

Abui.name: Abui
Abui.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Alor
Abui.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Abui
Abui.dialects: Atimelang, Abui Barat, Alakaman, Abui Selatan. Much dialect diversity. Alakaman may be a dialect of Kamang
Abui.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: west Alor island.

Tonsea.name: Tonsea
Tonsea.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tonsea
Tonsea.dialects: Maumbi, Airmadidi, Likupang, Kauditan, Kalabat Atas.
Tonsea.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Minahasa Utara regency, Kota Bitung and Kota Manado cities.

Amarasi.name: Amarasi

Amarasi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Amarasi

Hitu.name: Hitu

Yelmek.name: Yelmek

Yelmek.location: Papua province: Merauke regency south coast, east Muli strait.

Boano.name: Boano
Boano.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, West, Hoamoal

Moni.name: Moni

Moni.location: Papua province: central highlands, northeast Lake Paniai area.

Salas.name: Salas

Salas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Salas

Salas.language_use: Shifting to Masiwang [bnf] (Wurm 2007). Also use Masiwang [bnf].
Salas.location: Maluku province: Seram Bagian Timur regency, Gunung village on Seram island northeast coast.

Uruangnirin.name: Uruangnirin
Uruangnirin.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, North Bomberai
Uruangnirin.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Uruangnirin
Uruangnirin.other_comments: Blust (1991) says this appears to be Central Malayo-Polynesian. Christian, traditional religion.
Uruangnirin.location: Papua Barat province: Fak-Fak regency, Faur and Tuburuasa islands; southwest Bomberai peninsula mainland; possibly Karas island.

Dampelas.name: Dampelas
Dampelas.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Southern
Dampelas.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dampelas
Dampelas.language_use: Spoken in 8 villages but in 7 there are strong migrant communities and the everyday public language is Indonesian [ind]. Indonesian used increasingly in families who want children to have higher education (Wurm 2007).

Ormu.name: Ormu

Ormu.language_use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); potentially endangered (Wurm 2000). Also use Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Ormu.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency north coast, Ormu Besar and Ormu Kecil villages.

Galolen.name: Galolen

Awyu, Asue.name: Awyu, Asue

Murut, Selungai.name: Murut, Selungai

Yarsun.other_comments: Yarsun may not exist or speakers may have moved (2005 SIL). Christian, traditional religion.
Yarsun.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Bonggo sub-district.

Malay, North Moluccan.dialects: None known. Different meaning of particles from Manado Malay

Malay, North Moluccan.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 2005–2012.
Malay, North Moluccan.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera Selatan regency, Damar, northwest Jaronga, and south Halmahera islands.

Lun Bawang.alt_name: Lun Daya, Lun Dayah, Lun Daye, Lun Dayeh, Lun Dayoh, Lundaya Putuk, Lundayeh, Southern Murut

Semimi.name: Semimi

Sou Upaa.location: Maluku province: 30 villages on north Seram island mountain area; south along Teluti bay.

Dani, Lower Grand Valley.location: Papua province: Ndugu regency, Baliem Grand Valley central highlands; lower gorge.

Awyu, Edera.alt_name: Jenimu, Oser, Siagha, Sjiagha, Syiagha, Yenimu
Awyu, Edera.name: Awyu, Edera
Awyu, Edera.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Awyu, Edera
Awyu, Edera.location: Papua province: Merauke regency, both banks, lower Digul river.

Laha.name: Laha
Laha.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Ambon

Laha.dialects: None known. Distinct from Sou Upaa

Laha.location: Maluku province: Laha and other villages on Ambon island south central coast.

Modang.name: Modang

Modang.dialects: Kelingan (Long Wai, Long We), Long Glat, Long Bento’, Benehes, Nahes, Liah Bing.
Modang.location: Kalimantan Timur province: 5 enclaves on upper reaches of Belayan, Kelinjau, Mahakam, and Segah rivers.

Teiwa.name: Teiwa
Teiwa.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Pantar
Teiwa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Teiwa
Teiwa.dialects: Deing, Madar, Lebang. Deing (Diang) may be a separate language.

Manggarai.name: Manggarai
Manggarai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Manggarai
Manggarai.dialects: Western Manggarai, Central Manggarai (Ruteng), West-Central Manggarai, Eastern Manggarai. Around 43 subdialects. Reportedly similar to Riung

Taman.name: Taman
Taman.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Bugis, Tamanic
