Taman.language_use: Language and culture are still vital.
Taman.location: Kalimantan Barat province: Kapuas Hulu regency; upper Kapuas river.

Helong.name: Helong
Helong.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Nuclear Timor
Helong.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Helong
Helong.dialects: Helong Pulau (Island Helong, Semau), Helong Darat (Bolok), Funai (Land Helong).
Helong.language_use: Helong Darat shifting to Kupang Malay [mkn]. Funai dialect endangered through intermarriage and urban contact. Home, community, traditional ceremonies. All ages. Also use Bilba [bpz], Indonesian [ind], Kupang Malay [mkn], Uab Meto [aoz].
Helong.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Semau island; Timor island west tip, and Kupang city.
Helong.typology: Unlike many surrounding languages, does not inflect V-initial verb roots for person or number; has long and short vowels; glottal stop, metathesis.
Helong.population: 14,000 (Grimes et al 1997). Ethnic population: 18,000 (2015 S. Cameron).

Sa\u2019ban.name: Sa’ban
Sa\u2019ban.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Dayic, Kelabitic
Sa\u2019ban.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sa’ban
Sa\u2019ban.location: Sarawak: Miri division, Long Banga’, Upper Baram, Long Peluan, Long Puak on Kalimantan border.

Emem.name: Emem
Emem.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Emem
Emem.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 25% with Yafi
Emem.language_use: Home, community. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Emem.location: Papua province: Keerom and Pegunungan Bintang regencies, border area south of Jayapura city.

Ternate\u00f1o.name: Ternateño
Ternate\u00f1o.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ternateño
Ternate\u00f1o.language_use: The Jakarta variety of creole Portuguese survived in Tugu until recent times (Wurm and Hattori 1981). Varieties also spoken in Larantuka, Flores; Adonara (Vure), Solor; as well as Sumatra, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, and Maluku. Varieties of creole Portuguese were also spoken in Banda and Ambon.
Ternate\u00f1o.location: Maluku Utara province: Kota Ternate city on Ternate island.

Mpur.name: Mpur
Mpur.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mpur
Mpur.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible portions: 1998–2013.
Mpur.location: Papua Barat province: Manokwari regency on north coast of Bird’s Head; also Kebar valley.

Bilba.alt_name: Belubaa, Bilbaa, Eastern Rote, Rote, Rote Timur, Roti, Rotinese
Bilba.name: Bilba
Bilba.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Nuclear Timor, Rote
Bilba.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bilba
Bilba.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Used as L2 by Helong [heg].
Bilba.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: northeast Rote island; Semau island; Timor mainland near Kupang.

Doutai.name: Doutai
Doutai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Doutai
Doutai.location: Papua province: Toli-Dou village southwest of Taiyeve town.

Maden.name: Maden

Maden.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Maden
Maden.location: Papua Barat province: Raja Ampat regency, northwest Salawati island.

Kamoro.alt_name: Kamora, Kaokonau, Lakahia, Mimika, Mukamuga, Nafarpi, Nagramadu, Nefarpi, Neferipi, Umar, Umari
Kamoro.name: Kamoro
Kamoro.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kamoro
Kamoro.location: Papua province: south coast; Mukamuga river into Papua Barat province: Etna bay area.

Dondo.name: Dondo
Dondo.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Tomini-Tolitoli, Tomini, Northern
Dondo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dondo
Dondo.other_comments: Most of the hill Dondo interact socially with the Dondo coastal population which reinforces the use of Dondo in a variety of functions. Muslim.
Dondo.language_use: Children receive their education in Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Dondo.location: Gorontalo province: Pohuwato regency; Sulawesi Tengah province: Buol and Tolitoli regencies, Baolan, Dampal Utara, Dondo, Galang, and Tolitoli Utara sub-districts; at least 25 villages.

Javindo.name: Javindo
Javindo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Javindo
Javindo.location: Java island, Jawa Tengah province: south.
Javindo.population: No known L1 speakers. May be a few L2 speakers and even a very few L1 speakers (Wurm 2007).

Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.alt_name: Sa’dan, Sa’dansche, Sada, Sadan, Sadang, South Toraja, Tae’, Taeq, Toradja, Toraja
Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.name: Toraja-Sa’dan
Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, South Sulawesi, Northern, Toraja-Sa’dan
Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Toraja-Sa’dan
Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.dialects: Makale (Tallulembangna), Rantepao (Kesu’), Toraja Barat (Mappa-Pana, West Toraja). Rantepao is prestige dialect.
Toraja-Sa\u2019dan.location: Sulawesi Selatan province: Luwu and Tana Toraja regencies; Sulawesi Barat province: Mamasa regency; possibly Makassar city, west coast.

Trimuris.name: Trimuris
Trimuris.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Trimuris
Trimuris.dialects: None known. Low intelligibility of Kwerba
Trimuris.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Mamberamo Tengah sub-district on Mamberamo river east bank.

Ambel.name: Ambel
Ambel.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Raja Ampat
Ambel.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ambel
Ambel.language_use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Home only. All also use Papuan Malay [pmy].
Ambel.location: Papua Barat province: Raja Ampat regency, Waigeo Selatan sub-district, Go, Kabare, Kabilol, Nyandesawai, Selegop, Waifoi, and Warsanbin villages in north central Waigeo island off western Bird’s Head.

Simeulue.alt_name: Defayan, Long Bano, Simalur, Simeuloë, Simulul
Simeulue.name: Simeulue
Simeulue.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Simeulue
Simeulue.location: Aceh province: east and west Simeulue island; Babi and Banyak islands.

Seget.name: Seget
Seget.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Seget
Seget.location: Papua Barat Province, west Bird’s Head southwest of Sorong, Walian, Sailolof, Segum, and Seget villages.

Enggano.name: Enggano
Enggano.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Enggano
Enggano.dialects: None known. Not closely related to other languages.
Enggano.other_comments: Not conclusively established as an Austronesian language, rather than an isolate with Austronesian loans. Christian, Muslim.
Enggano.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Stable presently; threatened long term if emigration and marriage with other language communities continues. Home, village, market, ceremonies. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], in civic, religious, and educational areas.
Enggano.location: Bengkulu province: Enggano island, southwest of mainland; 4 small nearby islands.

Waropen.name: Waropen
Waropen.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Waropen
Waropen.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Waropen
Waropen.language_use: Children have a passive understanding (2012 Y. Sawaki). Also use Indonesian [ind].
Waropen.location: Papua province: Mamberamo Raya and Waropen regencies; south Waropen bay area (Ambumi dialect), and southwest to Rombak river mouth.

Adang.name: Adang
Adang.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Alor
Adang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Adang
Adang.dialects: Aimoli. Because of linguistic differences and social identity, considered a separate language from Kabola
Adang.other_comments: Bilingual young adults show stronger proficiency in Indonesian
Adang.language_use: Adang is becoming more restricted in domains and is decreasing in population due to urbanization (Haan 2001). Losing child speakers (Haan 2001). Also use Indonesian [ind] (Hamilton et al 2013).
Adang.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Alor island, northwest of Kalabahi town toward Banda Sea coast.

Chinese, Min Dong.name: Chinese, Min Dong
Chinese, Min Dong.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Chinese, Min Dong
Chinese, Min Dong.dialects: Fuzhou (Foochow, Fuchow, Guxhou). The prestige dialect is spoken in Fujian. A member of macrolanguage Chinese
Chinese, Min Dong.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate in Chinese, and they use that literature. Literature. Bible: 1884–1905.
Chinese, Min Dong.location: Fujian province: Fu’an northeast to Fuzhou; Zhejiang province: border area near Luoyang.

Kurudu.name: Kurudu
Kurudu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, East
Kurudu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kurudu
Kurudu.location: Papua province: Mamberamo Raya regency, Kaipuri and Poiwai villages; Kurudu islands.

Liana-Seti.alt_name: Liambata-Kobi, Liana, Lianan, Teula, Uhei Kachlakan, Uhei Kaclakin, Uhei Kahlakim
Liana-Seti.name: Liana-Seti
Liana-Seti.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Manusela-Seti
Liana-Seti.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Liana-Seti
Liana-Seti.dialects: Seti, Wahakaim, Kobi. Lexical similarity: 66%–74% between Seti (westernmost and interior) and Wahakaim (near coast) dialects, 69%–78% between Kobi and Seti, 70% between Kobi and Wahakaim, 42%–61% between Kobi and Sou Upaa
Liana-Seti.language_use: Vigorous. Also use Sou Nama [tlt], especially Seti dialect speakers.
Liana-Seti.location: Maluku province: Maluku Tengah and Seram Bagian regencies, Tehoru, Timur Bula, and Werinama districts, 8 villages from east Teluti bay north to Seram Sea coast.

Dusun Witu.name: Dusun Witu
Dusun Witu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, East, Central-South, South
Dusun Witu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dusun Witu
Dusun Witu.dialects: Dusun Pepas, Dusun Witu. Lexical similarity: 75% with Ma’anyan
Dusun Witu.location: Kalimantan Tengah province: South Barito regency, near Pendang and Buntokecil towns.

Tsaukambo.name: Tsaukambo
Tsaukambo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tsaukambo
Tsaukambo.dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Komyandaret
Tsaukambo.location: Papua province: upper Digul river west side.

Bali.name: Bali
Bali.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bali
Bali.dialects: Lowland Bali (Badung, Buleleng, Gianyar, Jembrana, Karangasem, Klungkung, Tabanan), Highland Bali (“Bali Aga” (pej.)), Nusa Penida. Reportedly 2 distinct dialects. High Bali is used in religion, but users are diminishing. Speech strata in several lowland varieties (1989 A. Clynes).
Bali.other_comments: Nusa Penida Island variety associated with Highland Bali dialect. It is a scattering of villages with minimal influence from the former Majapahit Empire. Hindu.
Bali.language_use: Vigorous. All ages. Used as L2 by Kata Kolok [bqy].
Bali.location: Bali province: widespread; Nusa Tenggara Barat province: Kota Mataram and Lombok Barat regency; west central Lombok island.
Bali.typology: SVO; noun head initial; definite affix; causatives; 17 consonant and 6 vowel phonemes; non-tonal; stress on penultimate syllable; 3 sociolinguistic registers.
Bali.population: 3,330,000 (2000 census). 7,000 in South Sulawesi. Includes immigrant speakers in west Nusa Tenggara, west Lombok Islands. Ethnic population: 3,946,000 (2011 census).

Batak Angkola.name: Batak Angkola

Batak Angkola.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batak Angkola
Batak Angkola.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Mandailing Batak
Batak Angkola.location: Sumatera Utara province: Labuhan Batu, Labuhan Batu Selatan, Padang Lawas, Padang Lawas Utara, Tapanuli Selatan, Tapanuli Tengah, and Tapanuli Utara regencies; inland from Sibolga city area south, east to Binanga, northeast toward the Strait of Malacca.

Kubu.alt_name: Anak Dalam, Orang Hutan, Orang Rimba
Kubu.name: Kubu
Kubu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kubu
Kubu.dialects: Lalang, Bajat, Ulu Lako, Tungkal, Tungkal Ilir, Dawas, Supat, Jambi, Ridan, Nomadic Kubu. Related to Lubu
Kubu.other_comments: Territory rapidly shrinking, somewhat due to deforestation. Traditional religion, Muslim.
Kubu.language_use: For Kubu living in settled villages, L1 already replaced in all domains outside the home; for Kubu in Jambi areas (more isolated and less sedentary), the vitality is higher. Home. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], for education, religion, civic domains, and with other ethnic groups.
Kubu.location: Sumatra, Jambi province: Sarolangun and Batang Hari regencies, 2 enclaves, eastern swamp region; Sumatera Selatan province: Musi Banyuasin regency.

Batak Karo.name: Batak Karo
Batak Karo.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Batak, Northern
Batak Karo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Batak Karo
Batak Karo.language_use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind] in urban and migrant areas. Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Religion. Some young people, all adults.
Batak Karo.location: Aceh province: Aceh Selatan, Aceh Singli, Aceh Tenggara, and Kota Subulussalam regencies; Sumatera Utara province: Dairi, Deli Serdang, Karo, and Langkat regencies; Tapanuli Tengah regency, south small border area.

Sou Nama.alt_name: Silen, Taluti, Tehoru, Teluti, Tihoru, Wolu

Sou Nama.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sou Nama
Sou Nama.dialects: West Sou Nama (Haya, Tehoru, Tehua, Wolu), Laha Serani. Lexical similarity: 74%–89% among dialects, 69%–78% with Sepa

Sou Nama.location: Maluku province: south Seram island, Teluti bay area.

Babar, Southeast.name: Babar, Southeast

Babar, Southeast.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Babar, Southeast
Babar, Southeast.location: Maluku province: Ahanari, Analutur, Kokwari, Kroing, Letwurung, Manuweri, Tutuwawan, and Wakpapai villages; southeast Babar island coast.

Foau.name: Foau
Foau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Foau
Foau.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 35%–49% with Diebroud
Foau.language_use: The people want to retain and strengthen their own identity. Home, community, most domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Diebroud [tbp], passively especially by those over age 35. Also use Indonesian [ind], in school. Used as L2 by Abinomn [bsa], Airoran [air], Diebroud [tbp].
Foau.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Indonesian [ind]. Texts.
Foau.location: Papua province: Jayapura and Mamberamo Raya regencies, Kecamatan sub-district, 1 village; Mamberamo basin region on Dijai river.

Ende.name: Ende
Ende.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ende
Ende.dialects: Ende (Djau, Endeh, Ja’o), Nga’o (Ngao, West Ende). Some consider Li’o
Ende.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: south central Flores island.

Adonara.name: Adonara
Adonara.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Adonara
Adonara.dialects: West Adonara, East Adonara, East Solor.
Adonara.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Adonara and east Solor islands.

Kauwera.alt_name: Kabera, Kaowerawedj, Kauwerawec, Kauwerawetj, Kawera, Koassa, Tekutameso
Kauwera.name: Kauwera
Kauwera.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kauwera
Kauwera.location: Papua province: middle Mamberamo river, north bank.

Narau.name: Narau
Narau.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Narau
Narau.other_comments: 2006 survey data indicates language may not exist and could possibly be merged with Kosare

Seluwasan.name: Seluwasan
Seluwasan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Southeast Maluku, Southern
Seluwasan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Seluwasan
Seluwasan.dialects: Seluwasan, Makatian. Makatian dialect quite different from others.
Seluwasan.location: Maluku province: Maluku Tenggara Barat regency, Batu Putih, Makatian, Marantutu, and Wermatang villages in Tanimbar island group on Yamdena island southwest coast.

Marind, Bian.alt_name: Bian, Boven-Mbian, Malind Deg, Northwest Marind
Marind, Bian.name: Marind, Bian
Marind, Bian.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Marind, Bian
Marind, Bian.dialects: None known. Not inherently intelligible with Marind
Marind, Bian.location: Papua province: Merauke regency, Muting sub-district, Sanayu village in upper Bian river area.

Liabuku.name: Liabuku
Liabuku.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Munan, Munic, Western
Liabuku.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Liabuku
Liabuku.dialects: Quite divergent from other Muna varieties. Lexical similarity: 82% with the Burukene dialect of Muna
Liabuku.language_use: All users are older adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], Wolio [wlo].
Liabuku.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: Bungi district, Bau-Bau sub-district; south Buton island Liabuku village area north of Bau-Bau.

Matbat.name: Matbat
Matbat.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Raja Ampat
Matbat.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Matbat
Matbat.location: Papua Barat province: Raja Ampat archipelago in Misool and Segaf islands.

Petjo.name: Petjo
Petjo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Petjo

Tereweng.name: Tereweng
Tereweng.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Pantar
Tereweng.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tereweng
Tereweng.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: 2 villages on Tereweng island; 1 village on Pantar island.

Nduga.alt_name: Dauwa, Dawa, Ndauwa, Ndugwa, Pesecham, Pesechem, Pesegem
Nduga.name: Nduga
Nduga.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nduga
Nduga.location: Papua province: Jayawijaya regency, Tiom in central highlands, and scattered.

Yamdena.name: Yamdena
Yamdena.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Southeast Maluku, Kei-Tanimbar, Yamdena
Yamdena.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Yamdena
Yamdena.dialects: North Yamdena (Nus Das), South Yamdena (Nus Bab). A chain of related varieties from north to south with 90% lexical similarity between extremes, but with morphological and phonological differences. Southern dialect thought more prestigious. Lexical similarity: 90% among the north and south dialects, 47% with Fordata
Yamdena.language_use: Vigorous except for some northern villages. Strong users mostly over 30 years old. All domains, very limited use in religion. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], Indonesian [ind].
Yamdena.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Taught in primary schools, as a subject. Taught in secondary schools, as a subject. Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Yamdena.location: Maluku province: Tannembar islands, east coast Yamdena island, south to north tip of Selaru island, 35 villages; southwest Yamdena island, Latdalam village.

Sahu.name: Sahu
Sahu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sahu
Sahu.dialects: Pa’disua (Palisua), Tala’i. Reportedly similar to Waioli
Sahu.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Sahu.location: Maluku Utara province: Jailolo town area on north Halmahera island.
Sahu.population: 7,500 (Voorhoeve and Visser 1987). 3,500 in Tala’i, 4,000 in Pa’disua.

Citak, Tamnim.name: Citak, Tamnim
Citak, Tamnim.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Citak, Tamnim
Citak, Tamnim.dialects: None known. May be linguistically more similar to Asmat, but speakers want to be called Citak, not Asmat.
Citak, Tamnim.location: Papua province: Asmat and Mappi regencies, Epem, Tamnim, Wowi, and Zinak villages; Senggo town area.

Dem.name: Dem
Dem.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dem
Dem.location: Papua province: Western highlands along Rouffaer river headwaters.

Momuna.name: Momuna
Momuna.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Momuna
Momuna.dialects: None known. May be the same language as Momina
Momuna.other_comments: They have contact with Dani who are learning Momuna. Christian, traditional religion.
Momuna.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Losing its status as a contact language; being replaced by Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Momuna.location: Papua province: west Asmat regency into Yahukimo regency; lowlands south of main ranges.

Benggoi.alt_name: Bengoi, Isal, Kobi-Benggoi, Uhei Kachlakan, Uhei-Kaclakin, Uhei-Kahlakim
Benggoi.name: Benggoi
Benggoi.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Manusela-Seti
Benggoi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Benggoi
Benggoi.dialects: Lesa, Benggoi, Balakeo. Lexical similarity: 70% with dialects; 54%–66% with Liana-Seti
Benggoi.location: Maluku province: Werinama and Bula districts, Balakeo, Benggoi, and Lesa villages; Seram island, north Seram Sea coast.

Tugutil.name: Tugutil
Tugutil.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tugutil
Tugutil.dialects: Teluk Lili, Kusuri. Possibly several dialects separated by large distances. Inadequate intelligibility with Tobelo
Tugutil.other_comments: Forest people who have contact with village people when selling copra and purchasing supplies. Traditional religion, Christian.
Tugutil.location: Maluku Utara province: East Halmahera regency, Maba district, Miaf, Bebsili, and Marasipno villages; Wasile district, pass between Lolobata and Buli; North Halmahera regency, Kao district, Taboulamo area; Tobelo district, Kusuri. Dodaga, Tutuling, Akelamo, and Mabulan rivers in Maba district.

Konda.name: Konda
Konda.classification: Trans-New Guinea, South Bird’s Head, Konda-Yahadian
Konda.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Konda
Konda.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 61% with Yahadian
Konda.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong Selatan regency, Teminabuan sub-district, Konda village; lower Waromge river in southwest Bird’s Head facing Seram Sea.

Amahai.name: Amahai
Amahai.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, East, Seram Straits, Uliase, Hatuhaha, Elpaputi
Amahai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Amahai
Amahai.dialects: Makariki, Rutah, Soahuku. Lexical similarity: 87% with Makariki and Rutah dialects, probably 2 languages; 59%–69% with Saparua
Amahai.language_use: Pressure from Ambon Malay [abs] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).
Amahai.location: Maluku province: Maluku Tengah regency, 4 villages; Seram island in Elpaputih bay near Masohi town.

Dani, Western.alt_name: Dani Barat, Ilaga Western Dani, Laany, Lani, Oeringoep, Timorini
Dani, Western.name: Dani, Western
Dani, Western.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Dani, Dani Proper
Dani, Western.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dani, Western
Dani, Western.dialects: Western Dani of Pyramid, Western Dani of Bokondini. Lexical similarity: 65% with Obokuitai
Dani, Western.language_use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Wano [wno].
Dani, Western.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% semiliterate. NT: 1981.

Luang.name: Luang
Luang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Luang
Luang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Luang
Luang.dialects: Luang, Wetan (Wetang), Moa, Lakor. Low comprehension of Leti
Luang.language_use: Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], Indonesian [ind], Kisar [kje], Leti [lti].
Luang.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2005.
Luang.location: Maluku province: Wetan island, and across Wetan strait to northwest Babar island.

Ma\u2019ya.name: Ma’ya
Ma\u2019ya.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Raja Ampat
Ma\u2019ya.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ma’ya
Ma\u2019ya.language_use: Vigorous in some villages, shifting in others due to influx of outsiders (Remijsen 2001).
Ma\u2019ya.location: Papua Barat province: Raja Ampat archipelago on east Bantanta and central Salawati islands.

Pancana.name: Pancana
Pancana.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Muna-Buton, Nuclear Muna-Buton, Munan, Munic, Western
Pancana.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pancana
Pancana.dialects: Kapontori (Akido), Kalende (Lawele), Labuandiri. Dialect names are also place names. May be more than 1 language. Lexical similarity: 71% with Muna
Pancana.location: Sulawesi Tenggara province: central Buton island, east and west coasts.

Ot Danum.alt_name: Dohoi, Malahoi, Uud Danum, Uut Danum
Ot Danum.name: Ot Danum
Ot Danum.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, West, North
Ot Danum.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ot Danum
Ot Danum.dialects: Ot Balawan, Ot Banu’u, Ot Murung 1 (Murung 1, Punan Ratah), Ot Olang, Ot Tuhup, Sarawai (Melawi), Dohoi, Ulu Ai’ (Da’an), Sebaung, Kadorih, Kuhin. Lexical similarity: 70% with Siang
Ot Danum.other_comments: Dohoi and Murung 1 dialects may be separate languages. Traditional religion, Christian.
Ot Danum.location: Kalimantan Barat province: Melawi river watershed; Kalimantan Tengah province: upper south Kapuas river, 7 villages; Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai Barat regency.

Mekwei.alt_name: Demenggong-Waibron-Bano, Menggei, Menggwei, Moi, Mooi, Munggai, Mungge, Munkei
Mekwei.name: Mekwei
Mekwei.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mekwei
Mekwei.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Kendate, Maribu, Sabron Dosay, and Waibrong villages.

Serua.name: Serua
Serua.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Teun-Nila-Serua, Nila-Serua
Serua.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Serua
Serua.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Nila
Serua.other_comments: Government had moved them from Serua Island, south central Maluku, to Seram due to volcanic activity on their island.
Serua.location: Maluku province: south central Seram island, 4 villages.

Bungku.name: Bungku
Bungku.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Celebic, Eastern, Southeastern, Bungku-Tolaki, Eastern, East Coast
Bungku.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bungku
Bungku.dialects: Bungku, Routa, Tulambatu, Torete (To Rete), Landawe, Waia. Lexical similarity: 81% with Torete, Waia, Tulambatu, and Landawe dialects; 38% with Pamona dialects
Bungku.language_use: LWC before independence. Also use Indonesian [ind].
Bungku.location: Sulawesi Tengah province: Bungku Selatan, Bungku Tengah, and Bungku Utara sub-districts, about 45 coastal villages from Mondeodo south to Kenduri area; Sulawesi Tenggara province: Konawe regency, Asera, Soropia, and Lasolo sub-districts, Tulambatu and Kenduri areas inland, interior enclave southeast of Lake Poso.

Siang.name: Siang
Siang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, West, North
Siang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Siang
Siang.location: Kalimantan Tengah province: Murung Raya regency, Barito river north along tributary.

Lisabata-Nuniali.name: Lisabata-Nuniali
Lisabata-Nuniali.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Three Rivers, Amalumute, Northwest Seram
Lisabata-Nuniali.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lisabata-Nuniali
Lisabata-Nuniali.dialects: Lisabata-Timur, Nuniali, Sukaraja, Kawa. Lexical similarity: between Kawa (far western) and Lisabata Timur (far eastern) dialects is 85%, 72% with Naka’ela
Lisabata-Nuniali.language_use: Vigorous, except in Kawa. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].
Lisabata-Nuniali.location: Maluku province: 5 villages on west and north Seram island.

Pantar, Western.alt_name: Lamma, Lamma’, Lemma, Mauta, Pantar Barat

Pantar, Western.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pantar, Western
Pantar, Western.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: west Pantar island.

Leti.name: Leti
Leti.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, Luang
Leti.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Leti
Leti.dialects: None known. Marginal intelligibility and difficulty with written Luang
Leti.other_comments: Matrilineal. They share historical and cultural heritage with Luang
Leti.language_use: No longer spoken by younger generations (Hajek 2006). Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Luang [lex].
Leti.location: Maluku province: Maluku regency, Leti island.

Malay, Balinese.name: Malay, Balinese
Malay, Balinese.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Malay, Balinese
Malay, Balinese.other_comments: Balinese Malay arose as L1 in the Muslim community of Western Bali among immigrants from Southern Sulawesi (2007 S. Paauw).
Malay, Balinese.location: Bali province: widespread on Bali and Nusa islands.

Damar, East.name: Damar, East
Damar, East.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Timor-Babar, Southwest Maluku, East Damar
Damar, East.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Damar, East
Damar, East.dialects: None known. Not intelligible of West Damar
Damar, East.location: Maluku province: southeast, 6 villages; east Damar island.

Dhao.name: Dhao
Dhao.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Sumba-Hawu, Hawu-Dhao
Dhao.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Dhao
Dhao.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Rote Ndao regency, Ndao island off western tip of Rote island; scattered settlements on Rote and Timor islands.

Mairasi.name: Mairasi
Mairasi.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mairasi
Mairasi.dialects: Northeastern Mairasi. Reportedly similar to Semimi
Mairasi.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 2004.
Mairasi.location: Papua province; Papua Barat province: Bomberai peninsula, southwest coast facing Arafura Sea, southeast from Arguni bay.

Blagar.name: Blagar
Blagar.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Pantar
Blagar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Blagar
Blagar.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: east Pantar, north Pura, and south Ternate islands.

Ile Ape.name: Ile Ape
Ile Ape.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ile Ape
Ile Ape.dialects: North Ile Ape, South Ile Ape.
Ile Ape.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Lembata regency, north Lomblem island, Ile Ape peninsula and inland.

Sumbawa.name: Sumbawa
Sumbawa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sumbawa
Sumbawa.location: Nusa Tenggara Barat province: Sumbawa and Moyo islands.

Nuaulu, North.name: Nuaulu, North
Nuaulu, North.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Sawai-Nuaulu
Nuaulu, North.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nuaulu, North
Nuaulu, North.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 67% with South Nuaulu
Nuaulu, North.location: Maluku province: 2 villages on Seram island, central north coast and inland, and Saleman bay.

Mongondow.name: Mongondow
Mongondow.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Gorontalo-Mongondow, Mongondowic
Mongondow.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Mongondow
Mongondow.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Bolaang Mongondow, Bolaang Mongondow Selatan, and Bolaang Mongondow Timur regencies; north peninsula, Nanasi town west to Bijaj river; south side, southwest of Rototok almost to Kombot town.

Nasal.name: Nasal
Nasal.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Nasal
Nasal.dialects: None known. Not closely related to surrounding languages, but heavy loans from Lampung
Nasal.language_use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes.
Nasal.location: Bengkulu province: Kaur regency, Gedung Menung, Tanjung Baru, and Tanjung Betuah villages in Nasal river area on Sumatra.

Klon.name: Klon
Klon.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Alor
Klon.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Klon
Klon.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Alor regency, Halerman, Manatang, Margera, Probur, Probur Utara, and Tribur villages.

Pom.name: Pom
Pom.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Yapen, Central-Western
Pom.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pom
Pom.location: Papua province: Kepulauan Yapen regency, Mias Endi, Pom, and Serewen villages on Yapen island, from Pon bay west to Woko point; some on east Num island.

Keijar.name: Keijar
Keijar.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Keijar
Keijar.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 45% with Berik
Keijar.language_use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Young children seldom speak the language. Also use Anus [auq], Indonesian [ind].
Keijar.location: Papua province: Pacific coast east, north of Tor river mouth.

Airoran.name: Airoran
Airoran.classification: Tor-Kwerba, Greater Kwerba, Kwerba, West Coast
Airoran.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Airoran
Airoran.language_use: Religious services. Also use Foau [flh]. Used as L2 by Samarokena [tmj].
Airoran.location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Mamberamo Hilir and Pantai Barat sub-districts, Isirania, Motobiak, Subu, and other villages on lower Apauwer river.

Liki.name: Liki
Liki.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Sarmi
Liki.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Liki
Liki.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Sobei
Liki.language_use: Not used by youth. Adults more. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Liki.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Sarmi sub-district, Liki and Nirumoar islands.

Pagu.name: Pagu
Pagu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Pagu
Pagu.location: Maluku Utara province: Halmahera Utara regency on lower Kao river and west to interior foothills.

Sempan.name: Sempan
Sempan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sempan
Sempan.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Kamoro
Sempan.location: Papua province: middle south coast, between Agats and Kokonao.

Kembayan.name: Kembayan
Kembayan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kembayan
Kembayan.location: Kalimantan Barat province: Balaikarangan and Kembayan to Sarawak border area.

Ekari.alt_name: Ekagi, Kapauku, Me Mana, Mee Mana, Tapiro
Ekari.name: Ekari
Ekari.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ekari
Ekari.dialects: Simori, Yabi (Jabi), Mapiya-Kegata, Mee. Reportedly most similar to Wolani
Ekari.location: Papua province: Deiya, Dogiyai, Intan Jaya, north Mimika, south Nabire, and Paniai regencies in west central highlands and Lake Paniai area; Papua Barat province: Kaimana regency south-southwest.

Ke\u2019o.name: Ke’o
Ke\u2019o.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Ke’o
Ke\u2019o.dialects: None known. Reportedly distinct from but most similar to Nage
Ke\u2019o.other_comments: People and language are both called Ke’o. Muslim, Christian, traditional religion.
Ke\u2019o.language_use: All domains, ceremonies, personal letter-writing. All ages.
Ke\u2019o.language_development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Indonesian [ind]. Literacy program by government for adults and in schools.
Ke\u2019o.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: 4 villages on south central Flores island.
Ke\u2019o.typology: SVO; isolating language; 4-way phonemic stop distinction.

Kula.name: Kula
Kula.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kula
Kula.dialects: Iramang, Kula, Kulatela, Watena, Larena, Kula Watena, Sumang, Arumaka. Reportedly structurally similar to Sawila
Kula.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Alor island, northeast coast, Kiralela, Koilela, Maukuru, Peisaka, and Takala villages; also east central mountains.

Asilulu.name: Asilulu
Asilulu.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Central Maluku, East, Seram, Nunusaku, Piru Bay, West, Asilulu
Asilulu.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Asilulu
Asilulu.dialects: Asilulu, Ureng, Negeri Lima (Henalima, Lima). Lexical similarity: 88% with Asilulu and the Negeri Lima dialect, 78%–82% with Seit-Kaitetu
Asilulu.location: Maluku province: Asilulu, Negeri Lima, and Ureng, villages. Northwest Ambon island and west Seram island, Hoamoal peninsula, south coast.

Sikaritai.alt_name: Aikwakai, Araikurioko, Ati, Sikari, Tori, Tori Aikwakai
Sikaritai.name: Sikaritai
Sikaritai.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Sikaritai
Sikaritai.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 86% with Eritai
Sikaritai.location: Papua province: Haya, Iri, and Sikari villages in Lakes plain area.

Riung.name: Riung
Riung.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Riung
Riung.dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Manggarai
Riung.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: north central Flores island, Kabupaten Ngada and Kecamatan Riung.

Lamalera.name: Lamalera
Lamalera.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Lamalera
Lamalera.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: 3 or more villages on Lembata island south coast.

Bonggo.name: Bonggo
Bonggo.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Sarmi
Bonggo.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Bonggo
Bonggo.other_comments: Bgu may be the name preferred by the people. Christian, traditional religion.
Bonggo.language_use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Home. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy].
Bonggo.location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Bonggo sub-district.

Orya.name: Orya
Orya.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Orya
Orya.dialects: Barat (West Orya), Timur (East Orya), Yapsi-Taja. Slight dialect differences.
Orya.other_comments: Uria is a misspelling used earlier. Glossonym: Warpok by the Nimboran. Traditional religion, Christian.
Orya.language_use: Children learn Orya in most cases. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy], Sause [sao].
Orya.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Some adult literacy classes. NT: 2005. Agency: Yayasan Sïp (Tunas) Irian Jaya.
Orya.location: Papua province: Jayapura and Sarmi regencies, Bonggo, Lereh, and Unurum-Guay sub-districts, Taja, Wamho, and Witi villages.
Orya.population: 1,600 (1985 P. Fields). 900 in Unurum-Guay, 100 in Bonggo subdistrict, 600 in Lereh subdistrict. No monolinguals.

Biak.alt_name: Biak-Numfor, Mafoor, Mafoorsch, Mefoor, Myfoorsch, Noefoor, Noefoorsch, Nufoor
Biak.name: Biak
Biak.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Biakic
Biak.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Biak
Biak.dialects: Ariom, Bo’o, Dwar, Fairi, Jenures, Korim, Mandusir, Mofu, Opif, Padoa, Penasifu, Samberi, Sampori (Mokmer), Sor, Sorendidori, Sundei, Wari, Wadibu, Sorido, Bosnik, Korido, Warsa, Wardo, Kamer, Mapia, Mios Num, Rumberpon, Monoarfu, Yobi (Jobi). Some consider Biak and Numfor dialect 2 languages.
Biak.language_use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Strong influence from Indonesian [ind]; younger generation losing command of it; many prefer Indonesian (Wurm 2007).
Biak.location: Papua province: Biak Numfor regency, Biak and Numfor islands; Yapen Island regency, north coast area; Papua Barat province: Mapia islands; Raja Ampat regency, Bantanta and south Waigeo islands; numerous island communities, east, north, and west of Bird’s Head.

Kaidipang.name: Kaidipang
Kaidipang.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Gorontalo-Mongondow, Gorontalic
Kaidipang.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kaidipang
Kaidipang.location: Sulawesi Utara province: Bolaang Mongondo Utara regency, north coast.

As.name: As
As.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, South Halmahera-West New Guinea, West New Guinea, Cenderawasih Bay, Raja Ampat
As.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about As
As.dialects: Lexical similarity: 60% with some dialects on Misool Island.
As.other_comments: Reportedly originates from Gag Island, west of Waigeo Island. Traditional religion, Christian.
As.location: Papua Barat province: Sorong regency, Asbakin, Maklaumkarta, and Mega villages; West Bird’s Head area, north coast and inland toward Warsamson river.

Kafoa.name: Kafoa
Kafoa.classification: Trans-New Guinea, West, Timor-Alor-Pantar, Alor-Pantar, Alor
Kafoa.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Kafoa
Kafoa.other_comments: The name Kafoa is not known locally.
Kafoa.location: Nusa Tenggara Timur province: Alor island, southwest enclave.

Tawoyan.alt_name: Tabojan, Tabojan Tongka, Taboyan, Tabuyan, Tawoyan Dayak, Tewoyan
Tawoyan.name: Tawoyan
Tawoyan.classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Barito, East, North
Tawoyan.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tawoyan
Tawoyan.dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 77% with Lawangan
Tawoyan.location: Kalimantan Tengah province: Palori town area; Kalimantan Timur province: southeast border area.

Tarangan, West.name: Tarangan, West
Tarangan, West.language_resource: OLAC resources in and about Tarangan, West
Tarangan, West.dialects: Southwestern Tarangan (Rau Jar-jar, Tarangan Barat, TarBar, West Tarangan), North Central Tarangan (Northwest-Serwatu Tarangan, Ra Jir-jar, Rau Jar-jar). 2 sharply distinct dialect groups with minor variation within them. Lexical similarity: 70% with East Tarangan
Tarangan, West.other_comments: Largest language group in Aru Islands. Christian, Muslim.
Tarangan, West.language_use: Vigorous. Home, community. All ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Ambonese Malay [abs], and the Dobo Malay dialect in particular. Most also use Indonesian [ind].
Tarangan, West.language_development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Indonesian [ind]. Literature. Bible portions: 1997–2008.
Tarangan, West.location: Maluku province: south Aru islands, Tarangan island west coast.
Tarangan, West.typology: SVO; prepositions; noun head Initial; 2 maximum prefixes, 2 maximum suffixes; clause constituent marked by word order; verb agreement; no passive; 15 lexical consonants; 7 vowel phonemes; nontonal.
